review: This is nowhere near McCarthy's best work, but it remains a work of radical genius. There aren't many novels in the world where such a sentence can beThis is nowhere near McCarthy's best work, but it remains a work of radical genius. There aren't many novels in the world where such a sentence can be uttered.An existential novel with nearly no plot, endless conversations in bars, ghosts, schizophrenic apparitions, low-core incest, an abandoned plot point (maybe), and math. There is NO ONE like McCarthy when it comes to dialogue and the discourse on existence as pertains to the unknowableness of the Human Condition is enough to log this book in the pantheon of WFT and OMG and thank god it exists (I'm hoping some get the joke there at the end).I kept finding myself wanting to reread the entire novel with a pad and pen to take notes...before I was even finished.My only gripe was that all characters had the same voice: stoic, smart, witty. Regardless of status or position. Still, a flawed McCarthy novel that still ranks better than most novels. title: Antkind
author: Kaufman, Charlie
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Remarkable for its complexity and commentary, I suspect there will be a very polarized grouping of responses to this novel. It follows in the post-modRemarkable for its complexity and commentary, I suspect there will be a very polarized grouping of responses to this novel. It follows in the post-modern, (movie) theatre of the absurd tradition you either like because you also like to trip out, or, because you got your PhD in literature. Either way, it begs attention to the confusion and disjointedness of daily, contemporary life. In my opinion, this is somewhat redundant to most post-modern lit; as in, it was done before. Famously, in Beckett's novels that are very much at play in this novel. But Kaufman's awareness of that is what gets a pass.Others might think this too dense, pretentious, confusing, long, etc. It's both the long para and short para above. I gave it 5 stars because, as a work of literary art, one that I had to keep with me for 700 pages, I largely enjoyed the experience. Kaufman is brilliant and insightful, tragic and funny, and the book rides on so many contemporary issues: from identity politics to divisive politics. It forces you to pay attention by softening your focus on the absurdity and fixating more on the experience...wait, kinda like a movie. Eureka! If you get past the somewhat tired tropes of post-modern fourth-wall breaking and outrageous make-everything-crazyness, you get a book that hits pretty hard at middle-age American early 21st century insanity....more

title: Revival
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Stephen King can't get out of his own way, which is why we love him and are befuddled by him. Revival is an interesting book that starts with a very sStephen King can't get out of his own way, which is why we love him and are befuddled by him. Revival is an interesting book that starts with a very slow-build childhood, rural Maine chapter (sound familiar) and a tragedy that jeopardizes one's belief in God.Then it kinda goes off the deep end.But that's okay. I mean, what were you expecting here? I think the missed opportunity here was just that it didn't need to be a "horror" novel. It's as if, in first draft, it was the abovementioned philosophical text then King felt he needed to live up to his reputation so:-Her eyeball was on her cheek!and-Giant ants and a claw made from human faces!(I shit you not)So, I don't know...fool me a thousand times for thinking it could be different. Still, I'll read the next one; something about the prose style that is so magnetic....more

title: The Neverending Story
author: Ende, Michael
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What a unexpected joy.Like most, I remember the film from my childhood, but the novel far exceeds its cinematic cousin (obv). Interestingly, the film What a unexpected joy.Like most, I remember the film from my childhood, but the novel far exceeds its cinematic cousin (obv). Interestingly, the film only covers the first half of the book (which, I'm sure, has been, at length, covered) and that first half is clearly the best. I found myself, often, wishing the book would have ended where the film did. The second half, in contrast to the first, is a very German existential crisis s*itstorm that, at first, felt off-putting to me. I came around, however......because if you strip all of the wild imaginative stuff, and all the fantasy (mostly) mumbo jumbo, and politely ignore all the plot holes and loose ends; this is a very wise book about imagination and how important it is to survival up against an adult world that suffocates it. I don't count myself a fan of the fantasy genre, but like in all genres, when a thesis appears that has relevance beyond the invention, it's a home run.In a lot of ways, this is a grand slam....more

title: On Writing: A Memoir of the Craft
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I think this is a valuable and very casual book "on writing." I remember reading this when I was younger and (don't all laugh at once) an aspiring wriI think this is a valuable and very casual book "on writing." I remember reading this when I was younger and (don't all laugh at once) an aspiring writer. I related to it more then, particularly the parts about finding an Ideal Reader and an agent.The non-fiction, "off-writing" sections are the best. King's voice and prose is just like in his novels: nerdy and homely, attractive and basic. Direct and authentic. My issue comes with his actual writing advice. I mean, what if people WANT to use adverbs? What if people like theme more than "story" (he never defines what this means beyond plot). Also, he bemoans plotting, like a lot, which is supremely ironic because his books so lack plot that each thuds with a klunk at their ends. In other words, maybe he SHOULD think about plot. In general, however (and owing to the reality that he's a famous and rich published author), I disagree greatly with his absolutisms on writing....more

review: This daunting and haunting novel is the brand of genius that will be appreciated more 50 years from now than it ever could be today.Forget the 19th ceThis daunting and haunting novel is the brand of genius that will be appreciated more 50 years from now than it ever could be today.Forget the 19th century epistolary novel of a murderous mistress; and forget the modern pseudo-zombie (death adjacent) story about longing, love, and loss; and forget the political ties that bind them: Lincoln and Trump; and forget about the dreamy, intense movement of the novel as if through water: and you're left with Moore's uncompromising wit, humor, starkness, tragedy, and above all, absolute incisor-sharp writing.A masterwork, in partnership with McCarthy's The Passenger....more

review: This is a beautiful and delightful book. Tess Gunty can write and write well; it's amazing to think what her career will be as she matures as a writerThis is a beautiful and delightful book. Tess Gunty can write and write well; it's amazing to think what her career will be as she matures as a writer and takes on...I don't know...less obvious topics.My gripe with the novel is that it reads like something from an MFA program. I know it was; it just reads that way. Like trying a little too hard. The characters are all types. I didn't super feel for any of them. The thesis re: contemporary culture and mysticism is on the fringe of being fully developed. It has that: I'm-a-little-too-old-to-identify-with-the-writing-of-the-concerns-of-30-year-olds-vibe. You know: internet internet internet. But it doesn't ram it down your throat as much.Still, all that aside, it's a really good book. The writing is sharp. I don't suspect it will stick with me, but I enjoyed being in its moment....more

review: This "novel" is simultaneously self-conscious and self-aware; and because I have no doubt that Oyler is the sort who will read her Goodreads s (This "novel" is simultaneously self-conscious and self-aware; and because I have no doubt that Oyler is the sort who will read her Goodreads s (particularly the ones less than four stars), forgive the metacognitive second-personness of my critique here.Oyler's writing is extremely sharp, but the book feels like a message without a vessel. It's obvious that there's a criticism of our experience with social and digital medias, a half-interested take on contemporary feminism, and perhaps the erudite hipster-millennial NYC-transplant quasi-gravitas kinda-political messaging here. But I mostly felt a little bored and sad-for this generation (I can say these things now; I've turned 40!!!).Here's the bright side: now that Oyler has gotten her bildingsroman, roman a clef capitulation to the book publishing industry out of the way, she's now completely free to write novels that I believe will net her a big-time award or two. She's that good a writer. Now that she can (and yeah, I'm talking to HER) move on to literature: calm down with the complex sentences, pedantic NYC-ism, holy messaging; she's going to have a career of writing great books....more

review: For me, this was more of a three-star situation; but because I accidentally checked out the "young adult" version of the book from my library, I'm goiFor me, this was more of a three-star situation; but because I accidentally checked out the "young adult" version of the book from my library, I'm going to give Grande the benefit of the doubt that the writing and circumstances were somewhat better in the "old" adult version.That said: narratives like this are necessary. Literature has the wonderful and compassionate ability to connect a reader and writer over space, time, identity, and experience. This function serves to grow objective empathy for the plights of others. The Mexican diaspora, American violence against displaced immigrants fleeing poverty, and the separation of family in all the tragedy are situated in the foreground; and anyone, regardless of where they come from, can identify and connect. This sort of thing is necessary....more

title: Crossroads
author: Franzen, Jonathan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: With apologies to Mr. Franzen, I read this novel directly after finishing Cormac McCarthy's The Passenger, and absolutely no novel could withstand theWith apologies to Mr. Franzen, I read this novel directly after finishing Cormac McCarthy's The Passenger, and absolutely no novel could withstand the cataclysmic decline in quality of following that masterpiece.Still, and with further apologies to the horde of Franzen admirers, this novel is very bad.I could go on about the watered down philosophical religiosity, or the one-dimensional and vacant characters, or the one-dimensional and vacant prose, or any number of other infractions; but what really struck me is the 600 pages of violating the "sh0w-don't-tell" mantra of many a creative writing institution. While you'll find me no bastion of rule following, this one, in writing, seems paramount. Franzen has remarkably very few scenes in this behemoth of a novel; so rather than showing us the story, the feelings, the ideas, he tells us. That is: he just explains everything.Ex. Show: Becky lit a prayer candle that was quickly extinguished by a tear from her loss.Tell: Becky felt sad.For 600 pages. Hard pass....more

author: McCarthy, Cormac
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This might be an unpopular take, but I don't think this book ever needed to exist (but, oh, wait...maybe it doesn't. Maybe...what else?...nothing doesThis might be an unpopular take, but I don't think this book ever needed to exist (but, oh, wait...maybe it doesn't. Maybe...what else?...nothing does). It reads like the publisher a) was worried that The Passenger was too complex, unorthodox, and to unresolved for a traditional reader and so wanted an explanatory "coda" and b) wanted to sell another book. (Conspiracy theory: and c) had someone else write it [it doesn't even read like McCarthy's writing]).I read that McCarthy critics have landed upon his reluctance to use female characters. I think, perhaps, this novel stands as a testament as to why.The Passenger was a book about unknowing, and so the paradoxical plot points and open threads illustrated the theoretical motif. Stella Maris doesn't do anything to expand upon the theme or deepen the original rhetoric. In short, it didn't need to exist....more

title: The Plague
author: Camus, Albert
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I understand this book was supposed to be an allegory, that of human fortitude and will despite a metaphoric pestilence, and I understand this book maI understand this book was supposed to be an allegory, that of human fortitude and will despite a metaphoric pestilence, and I understand this book may have had an ancillary allegorical theme, that of the Nazi occupation of Paris during WWII....but, and OF COURSE, this book's relevance has taken new form after the Covid-19 pandemic. What is most stellar, inconceivable, and generally wild is the prognosticative nature of the book: from the isolating feelings of quarantine, to the efficacy of masks, to the morose's morose appreciation of disease; it's as if Camus traveled in time to 2020, took notes, and went back. I found myself constantly aware of just how true his account was of something that hadn't happened yet. Ironically, his metaphoric story stands taller than the proposed allegories.Great writing, and humor! (The author who writes one line the whole novel.) To weave in humor and humanity inside of dire circumstances, once again, nailed the actual. I'm sure this was always a worthy read, but is certainly more so now. ...more

author: Murakami, Haruki
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's so hard to begin. How do you write a  that's not mean? How do you write a  that doesn't belittle the thousands of adorers of this booIt's so hard to begin. How do you write a  that's not mean? How do you write a  that doesn't belittle the thousands of adorers of this book?All I can say is that this is bad: pandering, psuedo-intellectual, faux-post-modern winding garbage the author clearly had no hold on.I was invested throughout the first quarter or so, allowed for quirks and potential translation issues, but totally balked at Murakami's grandiose plop. I was totally out when Colonel Sanders showed up. This book is just so full of wanting to be everything that it ends up nothing. And please don't say I didn't understand it or that I'm too used to the modernist tradition to render value here. This is a book that the author half-planned, then tried to let run wild, then tried to wrap up when it got too long. I don't know why people love it so; perhaps because they feel like they should. This is the second Murakami book I've read, and I'm beginning to think he's a hack that's got us fooled....more

title: A Prayer for Owen Meany
author: Irving, John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I think this is a good book that would have been a great book with a better editor.This novel doesn't really know if it wants to be a bildungsroman, aI think this is a good book that would have been a great book with a better editor.This novel doesn't really know if it wants to be a bildungsroman, a social criticism of American politics, or a theological free will/fate discourse. They're all present, and it is mildly interesting how Irving connects all to come to a plot point. The problem with the book is that it wants to be too long. Irving, you get the sense, wanted to write a long, winding, novel; and does so by adding long passages that are largely irrelevant. He also, about halfway through, starts repeating himself. Here's an example that really isn't an example: "Own was short, so he couldn't reach the rim. The rim was too high for Owen to reach because he was short." I kept finding myself saying "I know already" to each second sentence where this happened.And I like really long books. I like being taken for a ride. But this just has too much wanting to be a big book. The beginning is really interesting and full of some keen writing. Then, just before they get to high school, the scenes lengthen, the writing withers, and I ended up just waiting for the final coda, which is foreshadowed ad nauseam all book.And man if this isn't contrived. So much of it is wildly unbelievable. And don't lay into me about believability and faith and whatnot, purportedly topics of the novel. I don't mean here virgin birth or precognition or anything. I mean basic things, day to day things, that happen in the book that would never ever happen. The reader has to bring his own salt lick with him to swallow some of Irving's fantasy.Still, it's not in anyway a bad book. I just think it could have suffered through a better revision to make it great. (see how I did that: said the same thing twice?). ...more

title: Eleven Kinds of Loneliness
author: Yates, Richard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a terrifically beautiful collection of fiction by a writer who couldn't be more unrecognized in the American canon. Yates's ability to craft "This is a terrifically beautiful collection of fiction by a writer who couldn't be more unrecognized in the American canon. Yates's ability to craft "loneliness" without falling on any of the tired tropes of such is genius; the characters are lonely but not in the emo high school sort of way. They experience typical and realistic aspects of life that are intrinsically and existentially difficult. This doesn't always translate to being or feeling alone, as many characters experience their "loneliness" with others or commune in similar feelings with companions. Still, the realities of life as it goes are not lost on Yates, who capitalizes on telling stories of typical anxiety with artistic flair.The writing, wit, and story structures are prototypes for how to write good short fiction, even if they can't teach others how to do it....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: We don't deserve this book.We don't deserve to know about a person, their history, their death. But such is the reality of celebrity; such is the notiWe don't deserve this book.We don't deserve to know about a person, their history, their death. But such is the reality of celebrity; such is the notion of our microscopic intent in regard to people we think we know, think we deserve to know more intimately.I came to this book because I wanted to know despite my reservations in wanting to know. I felt unresolved, unwhole, incomplete, as I had no license to feel but that I nevertheless did. I had made my peace with not understanding his tragedy because it wasn't mine to know. Then this book came out and, contrary to this peace, was immediately drawn to knowing. There's something about wanting that conclusion, that answer...and this book gives it. There is an answer.I'm not sure I feel better about it, but I learned a lot about a man I admired (from at least, afar), and more: I learned a lot about life. Listen, I know how hokey is is to say that, but I learned a lot, from learning about him, about me.And damned if that wasn't how his shows/books/media etc. worked when he was here....more

title: The Institute
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book was limp.That's the best word I can think for it. It is so entirely bad that I am actually in awe. It's as if King saw Stranger Things and tThis book was limp.That's the best word I can think for it. It is so entirely bad that I am actually in awe. It's as if King saw Stranger Things and thought, "Hey, I can write the Hawkins Lab stuff better" then had all characters (kids in the modern day as well as assassins) use the same corny Maine slang that is just his own voice. (Spoiler: he couldn't write better than Stranger Things).I can get beyond this.What is impossible to ignore is the lack of editing. King is so heralded that it's as if none of his writing gets edited. This book was so full of type-os(!!) and continuity errors that my head was spinning (the main character is revealed to have a sister on the 400th page that somehow was missed in all plot before AND after...etc.). Everyone involved knows that they could slap Stephen King on the cover of a book and it's a Bestseller, so they literally stopped trying. Related, there are all these superlatives on the cover that can't be real: "Might be Stephen King's scariest novel yet"; "Not a word wasted." What is going on here?Hey, I bought this from a Walgreens, so that should tell you all you need to know....more

title: The Crossing        (The Border Trilogy, #2)
author: McCarthy, Cormac
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book was full of everything we've come to love about McCarthy's writing: the clean, sharp prose, the profound insight, the connection to the natuThis book was full of everything we've come to love about McCarthy's writing: the clean, sharp prose, the profound insight, the connection to the natural world. It's ethos and mysticism are as poignant as ever. It's beauty, the fundamental poetry of it, as ripe as always.It's easy to see why this is such a beloved book. For me, it suffers somewhat from its own belovedness.In short, the opening "chapter," a self-sustained novella concerning Billy and the wolf, might be McCarthy's best writing, as in, ever. The work is essentially a model of prose perfection in every (obviously subjective) way. The unfortunate reality of this, however, is that the subsequent 300+ pages suffer by their proximity. The opening chapter's linear narrative and pre-bildingsroman expository discovery strand in drastic contrast to the following revenge, parable, maturation story. The later isn't in any way bad, per say, but they seem muted against this strident open.I do like the technique McCarthy uses to tell almost short stories through met characters, all of whom are trying to develop some sort of metaphysical philosophy about life's meaning: from ascetic separation to struggle with modernization. But in the end, these sections don't have the bite of the wolf....more

review: A second reading after 20 years and I enjoyed the brilliance of this book. Funny, I didn't remember much of it after reading it long ago and I don't pA second reading after 20 years and I enjoyed the brilliance of this book. Funny, I didn't remember much of it after reading it long ago and I don't presume I'll remember much in short time; that's how little the plot matters. The prose, on the other hand, is careful and intelligent. Woolf's stream-of-consciousness is, at first, so off-putting that I felt a dunce, only to finally adjust to her cyclical and repetitive rhythm and deep metaphysical contemplation. I've weirdly always thought that good books were the ones that made you stop reading to look up/out and think. This book took me forever because of it, so I suppose it's pretty good....more

I'm a Philly sports fan. So I liked it.Didinger's writing is (journalistically) well-crafted (that is: it's not poetry, but who came to this book looking for poetry?) and his personal experiences/honesty/insights are worthy. There's always an intellectual shame when you admit you like sports, reduced as they often are to frat-boy machismo; but this book helps people see why they matter, especially to the Philly fan, for whom so much of their energy and passion aligns with their teams not for some superficial thing, but because Philly fandom is correlated to city pride and, therefore, personal worth. author: Gaiman, Neil*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This really didn't hold up from my reading twenty-some years ago. I don't say this often, but this novel could have been two to three times longer. ThThis really didn't hold up from my reading twenty-some years ago. I don't say this often, but this novel could have been two to three times longer. That would allow for the plot to unfold and relationships to develop, which, as it stands, severely lacks from the narrative. Gaiman writes well, something often lost on the fantasy genre, and some of his ideas are interesting, but they are largely half-explored in favor of expedience. This might be due to the fact that a TV show predated the novel, and so the novel had unreal expectations to meet the truncated narrative construct of TV. Who knows?I did like the exploration of London in the novel, particularly how actual London mythology and locals work their way into the plot and characters.Ultimately, however, Gaiman could have written the same book more carefully, and ultimately, better....more

review: **spoiler alert** Look, everyone knew what they were going to get with this one. It's Clive Barker. It's overlong fantasy. Is anyone really surprised **spoiler alert** Look, everyone knew what they were going to get with this one. It's Clive Barker. It's overlong fantasy. Is anyone really surprised there are at least a score of plot holes? Is anyone really surprised at the oft-contrived writing or the protagonist extension of author or the inappropriate (in plot not prudishness) sex stuff or the unwieldy narrative or the predictability or the questionable motives of all of the characters' decisions or the fact that we spend 1000 pages getting to a Reconciliation only for it to happen off-stage? I mean: I went into this knowing all of that was what I was going to get. So I got to just enjoy the sloppy ride.Barker does a great job wrestling with his own relationship with Christian mythology and the ideas in the novel are actually cleverly rooted in such. I have an edition where he introduces the story and talks about how it was a metaphor for his leaving England for the US: also an interesting turn. The guy has an imagination and if you really just stop the pretension, it's a fun read.Are we really surprised?...more

review: This is a good book by most standards: it's thesis concerning the purported image of ourselves that we share publicly in conflict with our more honestThis is a good book by most standards: it's thesis concerning the purported image of ourselves that we share publicly in conflict with our more honest selves (and that correlation to the American Dream) is elegant; the narrative design of seamlessly switching from frame narrator to protagonist to secondary characters and back again is dizzying and impressive; the writing is often powerful.It does flatten. I'm more of a 3.5 on this than a 4. You can tell it was a heavily-researched novel, but ad nauseam. We get it, Phil, you figured out how to make a glove. We didn't need five pages showing us you did your research. In fact, this lack of economy is flagrant throughout the novel. Editors must have feared cutting from a Roth ms but man could this ms have benefitted from some cutting. Like, probably a lot.So at times poignant, at times trying too hard for poignancy. review: Every time I read this novel, I'm brought back to the beauty and humor of Foer's early work and/but (with apologies to the writer) am a little less paEvery time I read this novel, I'm brought back to the beauty and humor of Foer's early work and/but (with apologies to the writer) am a little less partial to the "experimental" nature of the writing. Of course, Foer would likely say this to his early-twenty-something self, and I'm not against anything "experimental," just when it's "experimental" for "experimental's" sake. Not all of this novel rings that way, but some does.That said, the absolute humor of the earlier Alex sections (seldom to I laugh out loud while reading) and the interweaving of the stories is exemplary. A novel about war and love, history and family, contemporary writing against tradition, the novel is worthy on so many levels, even when it's author wants to be cute sometimes. author: Zinn, Howard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is absolutely must-read material for every American, a phraseology (along with five stars) that almost certainly alerts the FBI and CIA. Zinn's aThis is absolutely must-read material for every American, a phraseology (along with five stars) that almost certainly alerts the FBI and CIA. Zinn's admittedly biased (he understands that an analysis of history cannot be delivered without bias) teaching of history focuses not on those in power but in the voices of the disenfranchised, largely through capitalistic systems.It is well-researched, written, and aims to counteract the evasive aspects of American history taught at-large by institutions invested in the lie that things like democracy and equality are primary principles of the American experiment. Rather, Zinn's honest look at how power corrupts flies in the face of proto-patriotic notions of a country divinely constructed. Some might think it radical, leftist propaganda, but I would call it humane, truthful, and supremely patriotic. ...more

title: Grendel
author: Gardner, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm late to this, and as such--typically--let the hype precede the experience. But for me, this was one of those novels that started with a great ideaI'm late to this, and as such--typically--let the hype precede the experience. But for me, this was one of those novels that started with a great idea but could not follow through in the essence. You know what I'm talking about: Phillip Roth's The Plot Against America, et al; author has a great moment of brilliant idea then lets the idea overrule the attempt at transcribing it.There are amazing lines in the novel: that one about will people murder less gently if songbirds sing in the forest (not verbatim), and I dug the existential dread of an othered monster, but seriously John, the similes. Every thing was like something, like conformist college sweaters, or like, machine cogs, or like grass blades, or like like like.In his famous book on writing fiction, he talks about creating and maintaining the Fictional Dream, where the reader is stuck in the narrative. I was shocked, reading this narrative, how little attention he paid to this pedagogy, as he veered so far out of the dream I kept waking to bump my head on the headboard......like a petulant self-flagellating priest....more

title: A Walk in the Woods: Rediscovering America on the Appalachian Trail
author: Bryson, Bill
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was a tale of two books, for me. I was engaged, laughing, and impressed throughout the first third of the book, before Bryson and Katz left the tThis was a tale of two books, for me. I was engaged, laughing, and impressed throughout the first third of the book, before Bryson and Katz left the trail. Like many criticisms, I was put off by the pedantry and egoism of Bryson, but allowed for it because the uniqueness of his AT adventure made for fun reading.When they left the trail, however, the book took a downturn. Disclaimer: I am an AT hiker but not one who believes there is some sort of pure way to do it: ie all of it or straight through or whatever. I think the trail belongs to each hiker and means something unique for each. However, when they left the trail, the narrative lost all of its focus. Replacing wilderness discourse were numerous asides about songbirds, global warming, industrial recklessness, etc. I'm not antagonistic to the agenda, per say, but it detracted from what I thought was the thesis of the book in the first place. In other words: it became very obvious that Bryson didn't write a book about hiking the trail but hiked the trail to write a book. It reads like he had an idea for a book rather than a real intent to connect with hiking, nature, etc. (which, his philosophizing seems to claim).There was also a lot of faulty journalism. See: he talks endless s*it on the Pennsylvania portion of the trail (ostensibly, because everyone does), going so far as to say there are no views and that it is all rocks...all without hiking ANY of the PA section. Additionally, for the sake of enhancing the drama, there were clearly elements that were made histrionic and (dare I say) were just not true. Like, the wristwatch on Mt. Washington, really? The latter 2/3 of the book, in short, seemed an attempt to just finish a book. He's got all the writing chops, he seems pretty confident (read: smug), but on the whole, there are better AT books out there...by a long shot....more

title: The Source of Self-Regard: Selected Essays, Speeches, and Meditations
author: Morrison, Toni
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've long felt Toni Morrison was/is the best writer of fiction in American literary history. This collection of non-fiction essays containing lecturesI've long felt Toni Morrison was/is the best writer of fiction in American literary history. This collection of non-fiction essays containing lectures, speeches, scholarship, and metacognition on her own stories/writing process further entrenches her in this title. The work is deep, real deep, like, a lot of it is over your head deep. I'm not afraid to admit it took me a few reads through some essays to understand her argument, nor am I afraid that I didn't always ultimately get it. This is the profundity in her wisdom, and sometimes language couldn't represent it, even hers.What made this collection particularly special was the criticism on her own work. If you're an author, this sort of writer will make you reconsider your choice of profession; seeing how she thought of and approached her work makes you realize how serious and dedicated you have to be to even enter the same room as her.I deduct a star only for the editing; a number of the essays have the exact same text reproduced. I think there could have been away to edit the redundancy to make the overall text more solid....more

review: It is interesting to read this after so many years and find what my own aging has done to my impressions of the book; certainly, I found (this time arIt is interesting to read this after so many years and find what my own aging has done to my impressions of the book; certainly, I found (this time around) the violence much more distasteful, even though it didn't hurt my appreciation of the book.I put this novel in the category of must-read texts on the dangerousness of cultural America, alongside Revolutionary Road and Invisible Man. American Psycho is a brilliant satire of unchecked capitalism AS a murderer of not only itself but the rest of us; and though it doesn't go so far as to locate the origins and deeply-ingrained structural violences of capitalism and materialism, it absolutely shocks the reader in its superficial portrayal of superficiality.It is scathing but also beautiful. I reduced one star (my teenage self gasps) for the fact that the violence, moving toward the end, does less to engage with the thesis than it does to shock in a lazy, overextended way....more

review: Fue un placer a leerlo en su lingua propia. Hace cinco anos que compre este libro en Cuzco porque queria leer un libro de autor peruano y lo econtre eFue un placer a leerlo en su lingua propia. title: The Testaments        (The Handmaid's Tale, #2)
author: Atwood, Margaret*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I need to say this LOUDLY at the get: The Handmaid's Tale is one of the best books ever written in the English language and Atwood is one of the best I need to say this LOUDLY at the get: The Handmaid's Tale is one of the best books ever written in the English language and Atwood is one of the best writers of our age.That said, The Testaments is one of the most disappointing capitalistic pieces of fan fiction ever to be born out of a TV show. I hate to be cynical, but this novel's genesis after the dawn of The Handmaid's Tale show stinks of get while the getting is good. This book!: where to begin. It reads like lazy, hurried writing, pretending through all of the boring dystopian tropes Atwood beautifully avoided in her first installment. Gilead, here, looks less a 1984 totalitarian regime and more a parody with not-so-subtle criticism of current American zeitgeist. Everything is boring, redundant, obvious, and pulls the teeth out of the brilliance of the previous novel that was less about plot and more about social criticism. This one is about branding: hopefully Hulu will pick it up.The plot twists are evident and obvious after the first 50 pages, not even close to surprising. And the writing, the writing!--the horror--is god awful. Atwood knows how to write! But this novel makes it seem like she had a 48-hour deadline and scribbled through an annotated history of Gilead rather than write a novel.Self-positioning: I was disappointed when I learned this novel was coming out; it was superfluous from the get. The Handmaid's Tale and its ambiguousness stand alone. So, of course, I was prone to hating this from the beginning. But it didn't take much for me to confirm my prejudices. This is bad. Money hungry, unfortunate, and bad....more

The thing that got me was how much "telling" she does in the book, which is something she does not do in any other work. In this book, for instance, to tell any character's backstory, there is a lengthy section wherein a character tells their history in a quick pitch. I prefer Morrison's other forms of narration; namely, her more abstract, circular way of developing plot.Still, the hairs I'm splitting. This book is still 10X better than most novels ever written. my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was my first time--late to the game--reading this and I was largely delighted all the way through. Sure, it's full of absolutely no-way happenstaThis was my first time--late to the game--reading this and I was largely delighted all the way through. Sure, it's full of absolutely no-way happenstance and wild imaginative scenarios, but I don't think it was meant to be realistic. In fact, as a hodgepodge of different Middle Eastern cultures' lores spread throughout time, it's difficult to think of it as any one thing. Still, what struck me most was how the cautionary tales of love and greed in cultures the West often does not understand intimately, pervade as themes in Western writing as well. In other words, the Tales, as myths of the Human Condition, translate pretty well....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I did not find this dense novel to be near the best of Faulker's work; it is harsh on the reader: long passages without paragraph break, neverending sI did not find this dense novel to be near the best of Faulker's work; it is harsh on the reader: long passages without paragraph break, neverending sentences, near-psychotic chronology. These things do not disqualify the novel themselves; in truth, there is a genius to Faulkner's ability to spin a story that seems to make absolutely no sense only to lead the reader to understanding exactly everything.There are some unique narrative tropes: different characters piecing together the wild plot, but even Faulkner jokes on occasion about how gimmicky the effect is (Shreve and Quentin become one, thinking the same narrative). It's quirky, and the writing is good as always, but the story does not hook the way some of the other novels do. The emotion, the hook and heart, aren't as there. It's worthy, in as much as no one can do what Faulkner can do, but it's also the weak branch of a strong tree....more

review: This is a brilliant and inventive novel that typifies the standard ennui of middle class white male malaise in capitalistic culture. While many readerThis is a brilliant and inventive novel that typifies the standard ennui of middle class white male malaise in capitalistic culture. While many readers and critics may harp on the barbarousness, violence, toxic masculinity, and nihilism; the novel reduces down to a love story wherein redemption comes from connection rather than destruction.The prose is excellent: well-written, unique, clever; the early Palahniuk novels really exhibit an author shucking conformity to write with brutal honesty. His criticisms of modern society, patriarchy and masculinity, capitalism, consumerism, and suburbanism resonate wildly and are embedded in genius plot and narrative structures.The end falls flat: it is rushed, more telly than showy, and kerplunks where the movie iteration soars (this is an example of how a movie can sometimes usurp a novel [I mean this only with the ending]), but overall, Fight Club is an absolutely necessary entrant to the canon of modern literature....more

I think, in the years since, there have been so many texts written to underscore this that Caged Bird doesn't resound as loudly. (I'm very late to it anyhow). review: This is a wonderfully constructed book pulling from cupboards all of the literary techniques that help propel a book into the canon. The strange firstThis is a wonderfully constructed book pulling from cupboards all of the literary techniques that help propel a book into the canon. The strange first person plural of the neighborhood boys, the beatified language, the plot spoil in the first sentence that the reader longs for while traversing the rest of the book, the theme of lost innocence in sexual adolescence and cloistering parenting...there's simply so much good about this short book that this box cannot contain. Eugenides is able to create a narrative that intrigues us with its humor and darkness as much as its prosaic notion of the things that effect us most during our adolescent development....more

title: The Plot Against America

review: This was nowhere near Roth's best book--in fact, it struggles the way many historical revisionary fictions struggle: with a fidelity to the idea over This was nowhere near Roth's best book--in fact, it struggles the way many historical revisionary fictions struggle: with a fidelity to the idea over the characters/plot--but the novel is utterly amazing in its sheer clairvoyance in predicting American fascism and its dangerous potential.Written in 2004, the novel is likely a response to 9/11 and the subsequent authoritative/isolationist principles of Bush America, but in no way could Roth have predicted how accurately it would represent the violent and prejudiced nationalism of the current Trump administration. I mean, the Nazi president in the novel even promotes an "America First" slogan. It's as if the current American administration read Roth's book (listen, I know no one in the Cabinet reads) and took pointers about how to start a fascist movement in a democracy.But perhaps Roth was privy; maybe he could see what was just under the visage of freedom and equity so celebrated in this country. For that alone, we can forgive the weak plot in the face of how a true artist understands his culture and time. ...more

review: I think everyone knows that this isn't really a good book. Stephen King is my guilty pleasure read and I love to be immersed in his really long, unforI think everyone knows that this isn't really a good book. Stephen King is my guilty pleasure read and I love to be immersed in his really long, unfortunately written works (I don't know why) but it doesn't have any real literary merit. The writing is hokey, the plot is laughably missing, the characters are all one-dimensional, and King has some serious, SERIOUS problems with women and people of color in his books.Still, I'm attracted to his page-turners. I wanted to pick the biggest just to get lost in a book. The Stand has some really poignant ponderings of how human society destroys itself, criticisms of instruments of war (biological and nuclear), and the endlessness of good v. evil as a literary trope. For all intents and purposes, there's a lot of thought here, but like all King novels, the book is killed in the execution.I'm being mean because I really do like getting into his books. review: In a lot of ways, the beauty of this book is in its coy subtlety; the reading is so quick and the plot so immobile that it could be easy to dismiss thIn a lot of ways, the beauty of this book is in its coy subtlety; the reading is so quick and the plot so immobile that it could be easy to dismiss the brief memoirs of a butler from a bygone age as a benign premise for a novel. However, Ishiguro manages to maneuver, into this tepid design, discourses on Nazi sympathy, class structure, the lamentable nostalgia of identifying with cultures from which the world has shifted away, one's own unreliability in assessing the self, and the dismissal of love in favor of misinformed propriety. All in only a few hundred pages.For these reasons, the novel is a brilliant representation of mid-century writing that reflects upon the more nuanced ways the world changed after WWII....more

review: Like most, I was a fan of Reading Lolita and so was interested in this newest offering from Nafisi. The opening section is full of idealistic optimismLike most, I was a fan of Reading Lolita and so was interested in this newest offering from Nafisi. The opening section is full of idealistic optimism that borders on the naive and the rest of the book is constructed of loosely-related threads of her time in Tehran and in college. There's a lot of lazy liberalism in the book: taking shots at conservatives with no real reason other than her trying to distance herself from a reputation of being affiliated with conservatives. But the greatest offense here is her analyses of books. Every Intro to Lit student learns that literary analysis is not plot summary but a profound, argumentative look into context and content. Nafisi basically just offers plot summaries and disorganizedly connects them to strange notions of Americana.She loves Huck Finn but her two other book choices get cursory glances and her random Baldwin epilogue is rich only when she's quoting him. I liked the argument that literature should be culturally more significant (even though her thesis is undeveloped and at times inaccurate) and, of course, I was drawn to her time in Iran, but her critical analysis and sentimentality were hard to take....more

title: The Goldfinch
author: Tartt, Donna
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was a bit shocked to find, after reading this, that it won the Pulitzer Prize. I like Donna Tartt, and have enjoyed her other works, but this one stI was a bit shocked to find, after reading this, that it won the Pulitzer Prize. I like Donna Tartt, and have enjoyed her other works, but this one struck a bit off the mark for me. There were elegant aspects to it. Everything before Vegas is well done. And the conclusion narrative is thoughtful. It's just that nearly everything in between (and I'm talking 500 pages here) feels like an author who really wanted to write a long book and so painfully extended the narrative to meet her own requisite. Seriously, the thesis of the novel could have been achieved without Vegas, without Boris, without the art thievery, and without the troubled writing of the entire middle section. It would have made a splendid short story, perhaps 30 pages long. What we have, and I seem to be alone here (though I am breakneck with quickness to acknowledge the supreme arbitrariness of any prize committee), is a really long book that wanted to be really long and even for folks like me who like really long books, was just too really long....more

author: Dennis-Benn, Nicole *
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a very necessary book that shows, paraphrased from the author's own words during a seminar at my college, the side of Jamaica that the touristThis is a very necessary book that shows, paraphrased from the author's own words during a seminar at my college, the side of Jamaica that the tourists do not see. In fact, the tourist business on the island is not mutually exclusive to the sufferings of the Jamaican people. This book should be handed out (PETA pig's blood mink coat style) to passengers about to board a cruise ship to the Caribbean. Tourism is a direct catalyst to the suffering.At times, I felt as if the victimization of the characters (though likely not histrionic or hyperbolic) was a bit forced to bolster the thesis, but having not had the direct experience that Dennis-Benn has had, I may be speaking out of turn. As a simple reader, some of it seemed forced. In other words, I'm sure Jamaicans have some joy in life or are in some ways productive. This text makes it seem like constant hardship every minute, which may unfairly create a victim-ideology surrounding a group of people.At any rate, it needs to be read to highlight a human rights oppression that occurs concurrent to wealthy tourism. ...more

title: The Great Mistake: How We Wrecked Public Universities and How We Can Fix Them
author: Newfield, Christopher
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've been following Newfield's work for awhile and am always refreshed by his clear, comprehensive, and justice-oriented critiques of American higher I've been following Newfield's work for awhile and am always refreshed by his clear, comprehensive, and justice-oriented critiques of American higher education. As is often the case with academic subjects, there's not a lot here that didn't appear in his previous work, especially Unmaking the Public University, but The Great Mistake may be the most compact and concise version of this theories. This book might be better for academics, administrators, and politicians who do not have the stomach or patience for more of the dense and research-heavy texts that precede it.My only criticism is Newfield's idealistic, hard-liberal call to refund public education just because it's the right thing to do. I align completely and essentially with every notion that he has, but I cannot see our politicians and administrators falling in line; there's too much capital to lose for them. But of course, this text was published just before DT was elected so I'd wonder about Newfield's optimism in this new climate....more

review: This book is all the rage right now not just because of Orwell's frightening prognostication of what has become the developing American totalitarian sThis book is all the rage right now not just because of Orwell's frightening prognostication of what has become the developing American totalitarian state, but because his systematic and critical notions of how regimes repress humanity are ancient. In other words, he predicted very little; what Orwell did was keenly observe what happened in the past to find a logical, cyclical happenstance for the future.Every time I read this novel I am simultaneously inspired and angered at what seems to be our consistent human lot. But then I realize I am participating in literature, which is finely grounded upon the notion that art undercuts oppression before its teeth are deeply sunk. Orwell's 1984 is required reading in the United States right now....more

review: This is a pretty important book to read regardless of whether you are entrenched into critical race discourse or are just getting to understand the coThis is a pretty important book to read regardless of whether you are entrenched into critical race discourse or are just getting to understand the conversation. Coates does not necessarily say anything new or different here but presents a very touching argument on how the American hierarchy is constructed on the destruction of black bodies. The informal, conversational tone of the book and that it is written to his son humanizes the oft-politicized discourse: his thesis returning to the notion that physical bodies are destroyed by racism and capitalism. Sometimes autobiographical, the book is a relevant addition to the American canon, especially when America continues to prove itself in need of these books to be written....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Disclosure: fan of Everything is Illuminated and Extremely Loud and Incredible Close.Full disclosure: not a big fan of this book.Foer is a rich and imDisclosure: fan of Everything is Illuminated and Extremely Loud and Incredible Close.Full disclosure: not a big fan of this book.Foer is a rich and imaginative novelist who seems to be getting away from his idiosyncrasies not because he is maturing as a writer but because he is tired of being called idiosyncratic by critics. In Here I Am, much of the unique writing and innovative ideas appear, but they seem stock: he has a notebook of cool lines and cool ideas that get injected into the book, and while they often enrich his previous work, here act like brightly-colored "put-down" euthanasia serum. His previous novels touch upon profoundness, call to the existential needs of a searching humanity. Here I Am is a conceit to this: long passages of trying to be poignant without achieving it. It is an auto-biography (his own dissolving marriage) without the suture to the rest of us. And the speculative future of dissolving Israel is reaching without grasping.There are elements that work: clever writing, Foeresque constructs, etc. But this really long short story does not pack the emotive Jew-fist punch of his other, more provocative work....more

author: Jackson, Shirley
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Shirley Jackson is a fantastic writer in that she avoids the structures and logic of traditional narratives in creating a distinctive voice by which tShirley Jackson is a fantastic writer in that she avoids the structures and logic of traditional narratives in creating a distinctive voice by which to deliver her stories. Some readers might find her "confusing" but this disorientation present is more than a style, it is a narrative trope meant to supplement the subject.Haunting of Hill House is not a horror novel in the traditional sense. There are elements of the supernatural but Jackson seems more intrigued by the reality of people whose lives, restrained to banality, find momentary excitement in the abnormal. A haunted house, then, is just an allegory for our ceaseless need to be stimulated when we feel alone and directionless. That, of course, is the true horror, and Jackson's positioning of this in a ghost story while examining the interlocutions of a struggling person, make this short book worth the time....more

review: It is not Mockingbird but it cannot be. Nothing could be.This book needs to be read--if at all--with a very critical eye. A meta-textual eye. And thisIt is not Mockingbird but it cannot be. Nothing could be.This book needs to be read--if at all--with a very critical eye. A meta-textual eye. And this is not the forum to discuss the unethical moves of a publishing company over an elderly woman, but perhaps something should be said in condemnation therein.The novel is a rough draft of Mockingbird that suffers from being an early evolution of a tremendous novel. Inside is some of the majesty of Harper's writing, which, in and of itself, is worth the read. But the novel is unfinished, unedited, and pales against its vibrant progeny.The novel does not jeopardize Atticus's legacy, as Atticus's final genesis is what we get in Mockingbird, not here. Still, it was viscerally painful to read him, what with his penchant for moral barometerism, say the terrible things that move Scott to vomiting. If it were a standalone novel, with different character names, it would be a find portrait of how the Civil Rights movement moved Southerners into a new brand of racism. Let's think of it that way, because it is not in the same family of the Finches. ...more

review: Ok, this may be sacrilegious in the climbing community (of which, I am a part), but this book made me dislike a climber I thought I would actually likOk, this may be sacrilegious in the climbing community (of which, I am a part), but this book made me dislike a climber I thought I would actually like. There is no doubt that Honnold is an extremely gifted athlete who dares to do things with rock that even the plates and all of their tectonics wouldn't have imagined, but the narrative makes him come off as a snooty, advantaged Cali brat with really problematic and limited perspectives of people not like him.There is a lot of sexism in the book (hot chick can't even tell the difference between 5.10 and 5.13) and a diminutive look towards developing nations and people (the "Third World" is not a phrase that is used in 2016; nor are ethnic clothes "funny looking.") that borders on the pedantic and suffering from the "white messiah" syndrome: "So I started this foundation to help Africa because it would be bomber environment environment environment" (not direct quote). The Cali pretension of vague environmental consciousness with Thoreauian disapproval of anyone's lifestyle but his (why would people want to eat meat, drink beer, and get married? Yuck!!) was so off-putting.The sad thing is, all this overshadows a book about some amazing outdoor adventures. It's not written particularly well but I can forgive because Honnold isn't a writer. And there is a chance that the book simply misrepresents the guy; or that my interpretation does. I just felt really gnarly and un-stoked after a climbing guru of mine balayed-off right when I was taking at the crux....more

I remember this story as being the one that inspired one of my greatest philosophical fears (you know, when I was 10): absolute power. Thanos's flaws in omnipotence and the supreme boredom that must come from divinity began scaring the beejesus out of me after I first read this. I instantaneously was adverse to all things powerful.Which is why I was a punk rocker in high school.And a socialist in college.Hokey in the way that all comics are hokey, but this one has some covert existentialism hidden under all the hopelessly inflated muscles and breasts....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: After hiking the Inca Trail to Machu Picchu, I thought it would be a worthwhile activity to read Bingham's account of "discovery." (Note that Bingham'After hiking the Inca Trail to Machu Picchu, I thought it would be a worthwhile activity to read Bingham's account of "discovery." (Note that Bingham's credited discovery is very Western-centric; even he doesn't dignify the suggestion that he was the first to find the site).If you're reading to find out how Bingham happened upon Machu Picchu, I think you'd be disappointed, as even Bingham didn't--at first--realize what it was or its grandeur. Rather, he walks by it, barely giving it a mention. In fact, this book is predominantly focused on other Andean expeditions; Machu Picchu is given cursory (thought beautiful) accolades only at the end.Obviously included are Bingham's patriarchal misogynies (women being forced to be photographed) and stereotypical Western solipsisms (savages!; aboriginals!).Half of this book is a fun look at adventure, most specifically the earlier chapters of mountain climbing. The other half is academically boring: lists of birds and the dimensions of buildings. Read for the former, stomach the latter....more

Such superlatives, in most caIt's hard to complain about anything in a Morrison book; she may be the clear and away best American writer of all time. Such superlatives, in most cases, are often hysterical, but, as I've said, it's hard to make a complaint against her writing. I give four stars only because Jazz isn't the best in her bibliography. If it was in anyone else's, of course, it would have six stars.A beautiful string of seemingly disconnected vignettes that converge ball-of-string style to emphasize the sensitivity of human relationships, particularly when they are strained against the backdrop of prejudice. Morrison has a running theme of African American disenfranchisement and the pain of marginalization in her work but it is never boring. review: I wanted to love this book. I liked it, really, but I wanted to love it. I wanted to roll around in a Rothian craze, become starstruck like looking atI wanted to love this book. I liked it, really, but I wanted to love it. I wanted to roll around in a Rothian craze, become starstruck like looking at the night with no light blindness at his medals and awards. I wanted to say, "I read the Human Stain, too. Look at us, accomplished readers, both." I wanted to close the book so tightly, insert it so neatly onto my bookshelves (next to its Roth kin), and muse a few feet back at what a good American Lit Jew reader I've become.But the thing is, there are some really faulty parts to what could have been a magnificent book in every way. The concept is remarkable, the commentary spot on, the execution a little on the wonky side. I found far too much emphasis on long paragraphs describing each individual character's less-than-necessary backstory. It was almost as if I was reading personal narrative by a rambling highschooler ("He did this, and then this, and then this, and that's why humanity is so damned.") Perhaps it's oversaid, but a lot could have been cut.Still, it features what most Roth books feature: excellent considerations, remarkable insights into the struggles of the human condition, and a little bit of patriarchal white privilege (his female and minority characters are really suspect; Roth's human stain is all over them)....more

title: Unmaking the Public University: The Forty-Year Assault on the Middle Class
author: Newfield, Christopher
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I think this is a must read for any american. The obvious problem is: it is destined to be read by a very very small class of people: left, progressivI think this is a must read for any american. The obvious problem is: it is destined to be read by a very very small class of people: left, progressive academics (this was assigned to my by my doctoral adviser). This has always been the problem with the West: polarized politics getting in the way of socio-cultural advancements.Still, it's an amazing history of Higher Ed in the 20th century, which resulted in a sustaining of conservative racial and class prejudices leading to a disenfranchisement of the great majority of people. Newfield is succinct and highly analytical in his approach. His thesis: the culture wars (right-wing attacks on notions of equality post-civil rights) developed an agenda to undercut public funding for public universities to marginalize a middle class such institutions helped to create. I used to tell my students that in the case of hegemony, there wasn't really some old rich white guys sitting in a room figuring out how to harm everyone else. After reading this book, I realize I was wrong: there most certainly was/is. He calls them out. This book made me angry at almost every page. For a person who does not belong in politics, I realize how much politicians do not belong in education. Still, they're there, and they're destroying democracy in favor of capitalistic enterprise. Newfield does not pull punches, nor does he hide his chagrin. The only drawback is: because few will read this, little will likely catch....more

review: There are moments of brightness in this rather basic book. Mitchner does not hold back his disdain for the Beat Generation and only marginally shieldsThere are moments of brightness in this rather basic book. Mitchner does not hold back his disdain for the Beat Generation and only marginally shields his more fierce criticisms of their admittedly idiosyncratic work. This seems very much a first novel: Mitchner exhibits an ability to write cleanly; however, the clean lines are submerged in messiness.Vince, the main character, has a characteristic pessimism (not very different from Kerouac's, incidentally) that might be over-typical for Freshmen college students: he's afraid of death, struggles with getting laid, is intimidated by peers and professors. The most profound reading of the book, surely, comes as a Feminist criticism of Laura, the novel's anti-heroine. Traumatized by a sickening abusive ex-boyfriend, she correlates sex to destruction and develops what in a contemporary setting, we'd refer to as an asexuality. Sadly, Vince cannot cope and jilts her. This is a missed opportunity by the character but perhaps a just construct of the author, in that, indeed, a dumb, horny college kid might be repulsed by prudishness, regardless of the reasoning....more

review: This book is confounding: there is little, even on the internet, concerning either the novel or Barry Targan, but I find it to be an absolutely fantasThis book is confounding: there is little, even on the internet, concerning either the novel or Barry Targan, but I find it to be an absolutely fantastic book. Detractors may argue that there is not much plot, and I would give them that, but it it tremendously well-written and its subject matter could not have been traversed better, in my opinion.Those interested in the student's relationship to academia will be especially pleased. It is a campus novel that does not follow the typical track of campus novels; its specific parameters are physics and the rites of passage of higher education, but latent within the text are how academia perhaps takes more than it gives of students, how literature is valuable to understanding the metaphysical, mythical unknowability of life, how the divide between the sciences and humanities are more arbitrary than our capitalistic culture leads us to presume, how, in the end, our life experience is what we construct in knowing ourselves.Very well-written, protag very relateable, nice hidden gem of a story that is, for all intents and purposes, unreasonably obscure....more

review: So, this book was of two minds for me. For one, I admit that it's the first "urban" literature book I've read though I'm not sure that tag is appropriSo, this book was of two minds for me. For one, I admit that it's the first "urban" literature book I've read though I'm not sure that tag is appropriate nor if it is reductive. I will say that I was pleasantly surprised with (and made nostalgic of) the use of slang in the novel. It was uniquely done; the characters' dialect fit with presumptions of urban slang but was written within the conventions of college-level English. Fitting, because the protagonist is in college. This last bit was very believable too; the oscillation between studying and "extra-curriculars" on a student's mind were, I think, fair.What hurts this novel is that it is exceptionally, apologetically, and abhorrently misogynistic. It reaffirms all of the stereotypes of sexism in the African American community without seemingly being aware of it. I feel like there was an opportunity to break down that construct and challenge the norm; alas....more

title: The Nigger Factory
author: Scott-Heron, Gil
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Despite it's inflammatory title, Scott-Heron (yes, THE Scott-Heron--as in, the musician)'s novel is an excellent allegory for the institutionalized raDespite it's inflammatory title, Scott-Heron (yes, THE Scott-Heron--as in, the musician)'s novel is an excellent allegory for the institutionalized racism in contemporary American education. Microcosmically, the concerns of the novel's protagonists are how to progress against the latent, deeply-rooted prejudices of higher education. With its origins in Greek culture, academia (note the Greek word) remains in a system of hierarchies which subjugates members of groups not associated with the hegemony. On Sutton University's campus, the black students no longer wish to participate in an education that falsely promises a future for them.At a macro level, the novel represents far more complex issues with racial progress, particularly within the black community. Earl, the SGA president, has ideas of using the system for the advantage of his people. The radical MJUMBE student group, conversely, believes the system must be destroyed altogether and be rebuilt. These interests collide with the black president, Calhoun, who has given up his progressive ideas for a seat within the academic hierarchy.Well-written (except for sentimental sections concerning boy and girl relationships) and poignant, it's also important to point out the occasions of sexism in the novel, suggesting Scott-Heron is not beyond recognizing the multi-layered effects of prejudice.Ultimately, Scott-Heron seems to advocate for non-violent approaches to racism. He illustrates the destructive problems that occur when peace is not available....more

review: After receiving this as a book suggestion from a trusted literary source, I'll admit to being disappointed only at first. The book gains a momentum thAfter receiving this as a book suggestion from a trusted literary source, I'll admit to being disappointed only at first. The book gains a momentum that seems exponential, lapping on itself with poetic (oftentimes histrionically sentimental) language that deeply resonates with the reader. A mixture of Korean mythology and social criticism concerning the problems of homosexual identity in a heteronormative culture propels the novel to its tidy ending, something of an exhale, something of a sigh.I was intrigued about how the Fee, the narrator, tries to rationalize his sexual abuser's pedophilia toward the end; it did not seem to strictly come off as condoning the act but rather indicated how Fee was using his query to deal with the remnants of himself after the abuse. This was an angle I wasn't expecting, which added an intriguing layer to the discourse of abuse.My only complaint is that the second narrator, Warden, sounded much too much like Fee; it is as if the novel was so much in Chee's voice that his characters spoke in harmony.Still, a beautiful book....more

title: Dubliners
author: Joyce, James
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In what must have been my eighth reading of this wonderful collection of stories, I recognized how my own aging--from Araby to Grace--and maturity hasIn what must have been my eighth reading of this wonderful collection of stories, I recognized how my own aging--from Araby to Grace--and maturity has offered new considerations to the work. I am shocked that a 20-some-year-old writer could have completed something like this, but then again, it was James Joyce.The stories are all disarmingly simplistic, all covert attempts to find universals in particulars, and though I generally do not think this approach is very worthy (I do not think anything is universal [how's THAT for a universalism?]) I think the construction is glamorous.The stories all trick you; they all make you think you've got them figured out while simultaneously irking you, making you realize they know a whole lot more than you do. Joyce's impression of Dublin and its inhabitants can be stretched to remark upon any city and its people, especially of the second tier (I write this from Philadelphia while Manhattan's skyscrapers shade my desk). Through the complexity, though, we get wonderful writing, superb wit, and one of the greatest literary texts written....more

review: In a sea of campus novels, this one does not stand out. Maxwell's writing flirts with intrigue but never enters the realm of beauty that he edited intIn a sea of campus novels, this one does not stand out. Maxwell's writing flirts with intrigue but never enters the realm of beauty that he edited into the works of his peers. He has a tendency to try and end each section with a thump, a downbeat of intellectualism and over-tried poetry that comes off more contrived than inventive.To boot, the one large elephant in the pages is the homosexual overtones between the protagonists. I'm not sure if Maxwell meant to be coy, or if he relied to heavily on fraternal platonic love that he was to assume his characters wouldn't draw the attention of Queer Theorists, but I felt there was a huge missed opportunity to remark upon a male bond that is far beyond hetero-normativity.It feels like he wants to invoke the subtly of the modernist era without succeeding at the profundity of the human condition often underscored by great modernist writers....more

review: Mike Rose is a strident voice in the effort to reorganize the structure of education to better represent students not part of the hegemonic majority. Mike Rose is a strident voice in the effort to reorganize the structure of education to better represent students not part of the hegemonic majority. This book, though mostly autobiographical, is more approachable than some more heady books from the same theoretical genre. On some pages, even more, Rose's prose even touches upon the fringes of poetry: a no-man's land for Ivory Tower discourse, but welcome.I subtract stars because I am less interested in Rose's personal life than his ideas; so perhaps this isn't the perfect book for me. Still, and especially toward the end, Rose makes specific condemnations about a) subservience to a reductive canon and b) a focus on socio-pollitcal-economic structures of marginalization rather than victim blaming the student for "failures," utilizing medical jargon to indicate sickness that stigmatizes the student for an academic lifetime.Rose doesn't dig to the root of the problem, but he shovels in the right direction....more

review: Brilliant beyond measure, As I Lay Dying's triumph is the subtlety of scene and action that buoys the complexity of metaphysics, existence, and familyBrilliant beyond measure, As I Lay Dying's triumph is the subtlety of scene and action that buoys the complexity of metaphysics, existence, and family. As the Bundrens negotiate their diverse reactions to their mother's/wife's death, the characters are themselves confronted with their own ambitions, all told with Faulker's chaotic-though-planned style. I read passages thinking he had no semblance of an idea about what he spoke only to find, reading more, that it was artfully constructed within the confines of his discourse.The southern culture and its class distinctions (see: town vs. country) are evident and well-articulated, and despite time and distance, the novel resounds rather stridently in a contemporary time....more

title: Reconstructing the University: Worldwide Shifts in Academia in the 20th Century
author: Frank, David John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book has some very serious, very fundamental problems. Let me first say, in full disclosure, that I am a professor in a Humanities department (EnThis book has some very serious, very fundamental problems. Let me first say, in full disclosure, that I am a professor in a Humanities department (English), so I note my bias. They, however, do not. Frank and Gabler are sociologists and do not make note of the potential experimental bias of their research. Granted, their data is collected well, but the interpretation of such is whimsical, reductive, and highly problematic.They base their ideas on the argument that the university exists to understand and teach universal truths: a hegemonic, Western, and widely opposed construct. It's been a long while since Plato's great Truth was valuable to anyone outside of the Anglo heteronormative traditions. Still, Frank and Gabler seem to think the Humanities sustain these hierarchies rather than topple them. I point to political literary theories (Feminism, Critical Race, Post-Colonialism, Queer, etc.) to suggest how the Humanities have in fact evolved to consider parity and multiculturalism when other fields (ahem, sciences) had no cause to do so.Their interpretation of the Humanities is reductive and misinformed. They suggest the only application of Humanities is in law, and somehow clump education, journalism, communication, and advertising under the social sciences. Hmm. They completely ignore capitalism and personal interest in the modern University, as well as the critical thinking, creativity, analysis, metaphysical considerations, problem solving, abstraction, open-mindedness, and communication skills that are vulnerable with a decline of the Humanities.Perhaps Universities do train folks for jobs, advance technology, and attempt to "map reality"; but they also develop the human--which is for what the Humanities exist. The Humanities are no longer dependent on the canon, the divine, or vertical hierarchies. Finally, they are so horrifically redundant in their writing; they could use a good English major to help them edit. Too bad they won't exist much longer....more

He's well-read, using tropes from Brown's "The Escape" through Western Africa's slave castles, and does so with the postmodern elements of meta-fiction and anachronism. This last thing emphasizes how the racism of the past, though popularly a thing of the past, is still very much part of our world today. This is a great book for examining history and criticizing its missteps. ...more

review: Full disclosure: This  is only for the first section: "None of Us Will Return."Of all of the Holocaust literature I am reading (graduate class oFull disclosure: This  is only for the first section: "None of Us Will Return."Of all of the Holocaust literature I am reading (graduate class on the subject), the language of this is the most resonant. A question arises as to whether expository or creative memoir best serves the purposes of witnessing something as humanly tragic as the Holocaust. Not to discredit prosaic and expository memoir, but, as in most cases in life (who on GOODREADS is going to argue against this?) the creative wins out, at least with me. Delbo's prose, interlaced with poetry and stream-of-conscious, post-modern, repetitive writing adds a layer to the seemingly timeless and endless narrative we get from literature of and after the time. For Westerners in the post-9/11 era, the text does well to situate Afghan culture and its people outside the limiting scope of war and prejudice. To boot, it's told with the honesty and flair of a good travel journal: the central protagonist, Didier Lefevre is not always noble, not always tough, and not always understanding of foreign cultures.
