Coming from the sciences, it's interesting to see Levi's flair for the poetic amidst his idealism. Of particular merit are the first chapter and the chapter concerning the "gray area." Levi is quick not to judge, and scholastically attempts to position the terrors of the Holocaust within rational frameworks. His chapters on Communication and Letters from Germans are not as crucial to his overall thesis, but give added padding to a scholar interested in the field. review: So here's my bold statement that's not really that bold and barely a statement:Homer didn't write both the Iliad and the Odyssey. Sure, they both overSo here's my bold statement that's not really that bold and barely a statement:Homer didn't write both the Iliad and the Odyssey. Sure, they both over-mention Rosy-fingered dawn, and sure, they both concern the same dudes (and marginally, the same dudettes) but they are very different constructions of narrative. I like the Odyssey much more because, well, it was a narrative. People committed actions in a space that moved an intriguing plot along. The Iliad was too clad full of people rattling around in their armor and biting the dust. At least there was diversity (in plot, at least) in the Odyssey. And sure, it's still full of deceitful and crass humans, strangely interested gods, misogyny, and woefully incomplete notions of morality; but at least it tells a story!So at least now I get the concept of how Odysseus reflects the Hero's Journey. The only problem is that now I have to go back and reread Ulysses, which I'll probably understand more.Muse....more

review: I know it's only two stars, but I also know I have to give this a break. Of course, I'd read portions of both of Homer's great works previously: in coI know it's only two stars, but I also know I have to give this a break. Of course, I'd read portions of both of Homer's great works previously: in college and elsewhere; but this was the first time I actually sat down to tackle the beasts in one go.I give two stars because, in this case, I am valuing my enjoyment of the story. This is contrary to any academic or analytical approach, and it certainly doesn't do justice to the historical and mythological value of the work...I just didn't like reading it. Forgive the juvenile.Also, forgive the histrionics. There were some things I did like: for example, I found the bravado intriguing and the construct mandating that gods are responsible for the valor, cowardice, and success of man; something not too distant from modern religions' take on the concept. But all of that rattling armor; Achilles=Whining baby; Paris=Insufferable Coward; War Motive=Suspect-at-best; Gods=bored; was just too much. I know I read it too close to the chest and ignore almost everything I'm supposed to take from it. Deep down, perhaps I've internalized it. But, when I finished, I really just wondered why there were 400 pages (orations?)I do want to throw a spear now and sack something, son of Cronus willing.On to the Odyssey....more

title: The Bell Jar
author: Plath, Sylvia
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Although I do understand how folks may find the book tedious and difficult to appreciate, particularly the new york section, we must at least recognizAlthough I do understand how folks may find the book tedious and difficult to appreciate, particularly the new york section, we must at least recognize the remarkable merit of the text and its thesis. To date, mental illness, its diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment are studied but not completely understood. This is a look deep into the very human phenomenon through an artist's pen and mind. Plath doesn't go so far as to condemn patriarchal subjugation, but it is evident that underlining much of Esther's anxiety is the stifling expectation of female gender roles in modern society. Docility is not hers (she binge eats caviar), motherhood is not hers (she is fitted for a diaphram), sexual prudence is not hers (she dismisses her virginity and chooses a lover); but these are the ultimate things which initiate her pain: the burn of going against the grain. We are lucky to have it articulated so well....more

title: Using and Abusing the Holocaust
author: Langer, Lawrence L.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What's frustrating about this book is what is frustrating about many an academic text: the thesis (albeit a good one) is introduced in the preface andWhat's frustrating about this book is what is frustrating about many an academic text: the thesis (albeit a good one) is introduced in the preface and than is so redundantly mentioned that one wonders why an entire book was needed to expostulate on the same thing.I know Langer is a celebrated Holocaust scholar, but he isn't a writer. I like his concept: that the Holocaust created a sort of "deathlife" for its "survivors" and that the history of the catastrophe has been misappropriated by irresponsible texts and readings of texts that serve a psychological cultural need rather than truth.But what makes this text outright bad is the vindictiveness with which he presents his arguments. Langer is often hostile, angry, and unreasonably violent in his s. He seems to advocate for the belief that Nazi war criminals got off too easy. That isn't to say that they didn't, but he seems to put forth his own agenda in saying so rather than contemplate compassion, a word he finds to be somehow evil.He also makes strange and presumptuous claims about how Anne Frank (for example) would feel if she survived. The text became less and less academic and more and more self-serving.I just couldn't help, while reading the banal last essays, that he, a learned scholar on these matters, fails to see how his hostility doesn't counter what he so studies and shuns, but uses its own energy to call contemporary readers fools and those with compassion too lenient. In all, the points made were often good but the sinister tone of the author crept through in an awful violence....more

title: The Power of Myth
author: Campbell, Joseph
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: You're kidding me...no six-star option? I mean, just once; as in, if I could only give six to one book? Fine.I've read this book every few years over You're kidding me...no six-star option? I mean, just once; as in, if I could only give six to one book? Fine.I've read this book every few years over the last decade plus and more and more I've realized that much of the way I've grown to appreciate and navigate life comes from Joseph Campbell's teaching. While I don't feel like a kool-aid drinker in any pejorative sense, there is so much genius to this work that I can help but feeling energized with every perusal. Campbell's knack is comparative mythology; his thesis is that contemporary society has lost touch with the collective unconsciousness that myth explains as the human condition and the existential problem; his solution is to "Follow your bliss." Easy, right? It certainly seems so, when reading his words.What I like is how Campbell doesn't attempt to disprove any religion, but academically looks at the similarities all philosophies and religions share, where they came from, and how we can construct a master myth that helps us govern a life that is truly and mostly unknown. At times a bit strained, particularly with Moyers's feeble journalism (full disclosure: I've not seen the videos; this could come from the cutting for the book) and a wild (dare I say, limited) interpretation of love in the penultimate chapter, POM is a desert island book; perhaps THE desert island book, bar none....more

title: East of Eden
author: Steinbeck, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book is so chock-full of beauty that it's difficult to summarize it in a blurb. While at first pretty slow, the dynamic character development andThis book is so chock-full of beauty that it's difficult to summarize it in a blurb. While at first pretty slow, the dynamic character development and scope make up for the winding intro (although, perhaps this is his "In the beginning..." allusion that itself, is slow-developing). Strangely, the scope of the book is not temporally nor generationally wide, as perhaps you'd see in a Marquez book, but is more broad in its development and sure in its motives.I was particularly struck by the character of Sam Hamilton, who is one of the most endearing characters I've encountered in literature. He is simple, wise, and so attached to his circumstances that he emanates a feeling of sincere love for his life, which I view as something to emulate. Halfway through the book, when Sam and Lee begin to decipher the Hebrew of the Cain and Abel story, the prose and Sam's character really shine. The paragraph where Sam discusses his love for his horse almost brought me down. The story also has a number of meta-fictional asides by Steinbeck himself (interestingly, there's even a Roman a clef as Steinbeck includes a "John Steinbeck" as a character). These philosophical quips, along with the Biblical retelling of the C & A story, add to the genius of this work. The allusion, though obvious enough to recognize what Steinbeck's intentions are, is reasonably executed, and adds a unique perception of Biblical morality: Steinbeck pities Cain. The moral ambiguity of the Bible does not survive Steinbeck, and the novel comments on the myth of human experience while being true to the foundation of good writing....more

title: The Last Jew of Treblinka
author: Rajchman, Chil
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This memoir has much of what we've come to expect from Holocaust literature in its unflinching descriptions of incomprehensible horror and adds to it This memoir has much of what we've come to expect from Holocaust literature in its unflinching descriptions of incomprehensible horror and adds to it a lot of specific detail concerning the absurd efficiency of a little-known death camp. What is perhaps the most frightening of this particular text is how systematically organized Treblinka was and how absent of humanity the SS soldiers had to be in order to rationalize such fierce and ludicrous crime. Rajchman's story is singular, but it acts as a portal through which the contemporary world can glimpse and attempt to understand, through its own identity and consciousness, the tragedy that was specifically Jewish, and inarguably human....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There's always something interesting about Deconstructive post-modern literature, particularly how it reveals the disjointed realities of the contempoThere's always something interesting about Deconstructive post-modern literature, particularly how it reveals the disjointed realities of the contemporary day. This text, which seems to itself suffer from the horrors of the 20th Century (particularly, the Holocaust), replicates what Joyce did slightly better in creating a prose/poem series in seemingly random quotes from Rabbis and non-linear distracted prose snippets. There's a lot of great one-liners throughout and one really gets the lost and persecuted tone of the text, but I found the incomprehensibility of the majority of this off-putting. I am wary to say it, but perhaps I simply cannot grasp much of the genius that is going on here; perhaps it is my lacking knowledge of Judaism and Kabbalistic mythology, or perhaps I'm just dense with this one. At any rate, at times I was appreciating what I was reading and at others I may have read over lines while absorbing nothing. Like God. Like how I, myself, am here, in the words.Reb Jeff says, "The seed that is the sky opens the ground where Yukel got confused by the water which ripples, which proves God. Which is nothing." ...more

title: Distances
author: Singh, Vandana
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The reason I think science fiction is so hard to appreciate (and this can be generalized to much of the genre-fictions: detective, romance, etc.) is tThe reason I think science fiction is so hard to appreciate (and this can be generalized to much of the genre-fictions: detective, romance, etc.) is that the author's focus is on the production of the theme inherent in the genre rather than a fidelity to literary craft(person)ship. That is the case of the fallibility of this novella. It seems Singh was more interested in including dense scientific and mathematical hypotheses rather than craft artistic literature. Moreover, I found said inclusions--despite these being her foci--as quite watery at best. There's no real science here in the fiction, just a pseudo-conception of scientific principals that guide what could have been an interesting plot if more direct attention was spent there.Singh does create an interesting, though alien, world; and her plot has glimmers of intrigue. Space travelers (from a place that seems a lot like Earth, mostly because they're a$$holes) come to a distant land to convert a mathematical serum (ugh) into lightspeed travel technology, only to cheat the folks who help them find it. Meanwhile, earnest protag deals with loss of personal racial identity as she: sees math in all things (Cabal Judaism anyone?), has polyamorous orgies, and swims in math.A lot of things left unexplored and not enough things carried through....more

title: Yosl Rakover Talks to God
author: Kolitz, Zvi
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In the whitewashing of holocaust literature that can numb readers to the truest of human horrors, this piece stands out because its spiratual focus,coIn the whitewashing of holocaust literature that can numb readers to the truest of human horrors, this piece stands out because its spiratual focus,contradictory and contrary as it is, adds a nuanced level of ontology to the discourse. Not only do we engage with a doomed man who petitions god, does not lose his faith in god, then almost goes to far as to blame god and demand from him (all within a few paragraphs); but we get the interesting metafictitious journey of the text as a historical artifact, its contraversy demanding conversation on the validity of fiction in depicting terrifying reality by assuming empathetic experience. Yosl is so compelling that he transcends his narrative and, with a few publishing snafus, becomes the autobiographical author. He had, in a sense, usurped the agency of the author to instill his own voice in historic canon. I think it is our fascination in the holocaust which permits our reading of fiction to presume and almost wish it real. We yearn for the rebellious and vengeant victim who wrestles with his motivator (faith) before acquiescing to it. This text acts as a nice springboard to open up the discussion of what role literature plays as historic document and how readers' projections and yearnings influence text and even publication....more

title: The Quiet American
author: Greene, Graham
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Greene's well-written and deeply political novel about the absurdity of war loosely cloaked in a love-story. Greene seems unabashed to vehemently critGreene's well-written and deeply political novel about the absurdity of war loosely cloaked in a love-story. Greene seems unabashed to vehemently criticize both "old" colonialism (that of Western Europe, particularly of Britain) and more contemporary forms of colonialism, such as the global capitalism of America.The "love" story resonates mostly as the anti-colonial critique as both protagonists (English and American) jockey over a Vietnamese woman whom neither seem to really understand or for whom neither have her best interests. Most notably was the confrontation scene where Pyle admits to his love for Phuong to Fowler: amidst this rather trivial and modern-romantic scene, the characters seem only tangentially aware of mortars exploding around them and bullets firing; in short, life being taken, as they quarrel benignly over their own affairs. Naturally, this shows the more horrific idea of how the West presumes to know what is best for Southeast Asia and remains ignorant to the succeeding results of its presence there.Fowler also harbors some interesting philosophical parlance (mostly with himself): rushing toward death out of a fear of it, fidelity and morality in marital monogamy, guilt in partisanship during military conflict, etc.As short and non-complex as the novel is, it nevertheless holds a large store of criticism and beautiful writing....more

title: Almanac 2013        (Rust Belt Rising, #1)
author: Gallant, Linda
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Like any anthology, there were pieces that I downright loved and pieces that I thought fell quite far under par of the overall project, but in total, Like any anthology, there were pieces that I downright loved and pieces that I thought fell quite far under par of the overall project, but in total, the Almanac was a brilliantly constructed insight into post-industrial America, particularly concerning the East Coast (as the publisher, most writers, and focus seems to be on Philadelphia). Despite the regional roots, the book highlights a fundamental aspect of Americana: its blue-collar past converted into a present day destitution mixed with progressive promise. It simultaneously shows the horrors of urban poverty and entrepreneurial intuitiveness that hope to spring the metropolitan areas of squalor and disrepair into modern, livable homes for the arts and intellect. Being from Philly, I had the constant quivers of acknowledgement concerning both the troubling realities of my home as well as the things that make me most proud. For outsiders, I believe there is worth and good writing here to invigorate foreign audiences and lore them to our rusty beauty....more

title: The Sirens of Titan
author: Vonnegut, Kurt, Jr.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is not only my favorite book by Vonnegut, but certainly makes an argument for my top 5 desert island novels. There is such an enormous amount of This is not only my favorite book by Vonnegut, but certainly makes an argument for my top 5 desert island novels. There is such an enormous amount of wit, sweetness, deep thought, and enterprise in this novel that no matter how many times I read it, I am still invigorated.Vonnegut pulls out his traditional pinpoint-perfect cerebral humor, simultaneously criticizing the social institutions of capitalism, religion, military conflict, and celebrity while pondering the existence of purpose in existence.Humanesque creatures create machines to discover their purpose, fail in doing so, commit suicide by said machine, the machines send a messenger across the universe to say "hello," he's stranded, 200 millenia of Earth life is fabricated to get him the replacement part, then he violates his mission by displaying human tendencies. It's intricate and simple, absurd and astute. And while humans argue the purposefull/lessness of existence, whether it is chaos or design, it seems Vonnegut ultimately just doesn't care; with lines about the sanctity of love and the joy of dog ownership, Vonnegut seems more of a Buddhist than a scientist.And the clincher: there isn't a pretentious word in the novel. Reading my , one would be apt to think they were getting a Stephen Hawking perspective of the Universe and existence. Au contrair (sp?), it's written so basically, so meanly, as to get the most poetic distance out of commonplace prose. Only, and I really think only, Kurt Vonnegut has been able to do this so effectively, so beautifully.Greetings....more

All of the stories are interesting, though a bit formulaic (19-year-old girls, we get it) but I think that has a lot to do with magazine publication back then, something we don't really have an equivalent for anymore. Peaking through the formula, however, are glimpses of what will become his more refined and expert writing style evidenced inGatsby through Tycoon. review: I have a confession: Stephen King is my chocolate chip cookie at midnight. Whenever I'm inundated with dense, complex, and celebrated literature for aI have a confession: Stephen King is my chocolate chip cookie at midnight. Whenever I'm inundated with dense, complex, and celebrated literature for a long amount of time: see graduate work and my profession; I pick up a King novel to whittle away the time. Sometimes, I just need a little mindless reading, and King is a mindless read that I actually enjoy.Not an expert book by far, but of all I've read, the best of King's. There aren't the glaring plot holes or problematic lingos in this novel that exist to repletion in some of his other texts. Here is a "horror" novel that isn't actually scary unless you consider the very real ghost of alcoholism as a constant specter. It's pretty well done, a page turner, and (I think) works well with the Kubrick film. Real solid, Ed. And, so one lady rejects him, he moves on to her more homely but richer friend. Solid. Postcolonially, Scott seems a Scot with a double identity: championing English prettyboys over the savageness of the northern highland beasts he may or may not recognise as his brethren. review: I was disappointed with this book nearly from start to finish. The characters are all muted, disengaging humans, and the structure of the book is weakI was disappointed with this book nearly from start to finish. The characters are all muted, disengaging humans, and the structure of the book is weak. Worst, the writing is YA or prepubescent at best; it's as if Stephanie Meyer ghostwrote for Eug while he was on his Pulitzer appearance tour and he agreed to publish under his name without reading whatever the most shameful member of the canon came up with. Or maybe he died and his publisher is trying to make money off of his name by getting chimpanzees to learn English and write novels with their toes. Or maybe you win a prestigious prize for a very good book (Middlesex) and therefore, no one critiques your work ever again. Or maybe, J-Eug had a bad acid flashback that took him to college and had him recall what was repressed. Or maybe, he wants to be a Prof somewhere where lit theory is big and wants to prove to the faculty he knows the theorists, or at least how to name drop them. Or maybe one of his friends one night bet him he wouldn't slip the word "boner" into his next book (joke's on that friend). Or maybe he never wrote Middlesex; maybe Shakespeare did.Whatever, the book is bad.I was going to give it two stars, because I reserve one for garbage so rank one should not sit alone in a room with the tome let alone read it, but it dropped to one because of the very end. It was going so strong, and reading the last page, I thought there was going to be some redemption for my beplagued author--but, (and instead of ruining the end for any imaginary readers of these s, I'll just leave this) he should have changed the last words to, "I do." review: Rustic boy-joy action adventure tale full of people getting "brained" by tomahawks and shot by single-load rifles. Cooper sides with the adventurism oRustic boy-joy action adventure tale full of people getting "brained" by tomahawks and shot by single-load rifles. Cooper sides with the adventurism of the wilderness frontier life and offers interesting if not what has become prototypical insight into the Native American question of history: what European colonialism and manifest destiny had done to genocide an entire race. Cooper favors the virtues of the wild over those of civilization, painting his "civilized" characters as stupid and incapable of survival. As this is as much a tale of bravado as anything else, he takes this a step further by painting women as essentially useless (oh, and singers too). Feminists aren't going to like that. "Girl sees a savage then passes out so dead-weightly that she must be carried by the valiant Indian hero who can, strangely, speak English and French!"Even though we can laugh at some of Cooper's reinforcement of outdated stereotypes, we can at least, New Historically, see a perspective of the Native American question from the 19th century with pretty good writing.As Uncas would say, "Hugh." review: Always good to reread a good read and write a good rev on Goodreads.Hem didn't win the Nobel Prize for this novel as the Prize is awarded to a body ofAlways good to reread a good read and write a good rev on Goodreads.Hem didn't win the Nobel Prize for this novel as the Prize is awarded to a body of work, even if that body of work is eventually eaten to its massive skeletal remains by greedy third-wife's posthumous release obsession.The novella/short story is nowhere near Hemingway's best; it has none of the literary flair of his more celebrated works, and operates better as an allegory or parable than it does a narrative. It reflects well Hem's late-in-life sadness and critical failures as a writer, sending Santiago not into death, but into the end of life, where faculties (luck, as he calls it) are lost and the final throes are near. Some interesting messianic references here: the beaten savior; humble, falling under the weight of his mast, metaphor toward end about saying "Ay" when nails are driven through palms. Is Hem's concept: Me=Santiago=Jesus? Who knows?I especially liked the shot at tourists at the very end who don't know the difference between a shark and a marlin. Hem loved to be an aficionado wherever he traveled: adept at the world of bullfighting, marlin fishing, elephant hunting, whatever; it must have bothered/amused him to see people alight from cruiseboats for overpriced Mai Thais at Bubba Gump restaurants (I know they didn't exist then, leave it alone) who bought Havana fridge magnets before reembarking on their sailing hotel. What's true is that two nights ago a dog bit my hand. This is how it happened. I don't want to tell how it happened. It was St. Patty's Day and, avoiding the drunk tarts and jocks on South Street, I went home to my family (in a town I don't remember the name of) and had corn beef and mashed potatoes. My little dog got into a fight with my Auntie's dog and when I pulled them apart, I got a nice chunk bit from my arse. Which was really my hand. So it's swollen the size of my head. It's my coordinated hand; I can't remember which. It doesn't matter. So, forgive me, but I can't write a . I've written too much anyway. This sentence alone is taking me 45 minutes. One digit, tapping each key in succession, pointing like an old man who missed the typewriter era. No home row keys. title: Cloud Atlas
author: Mitchell, David
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In what surely amounts to be the best book I've read in many years, Cloud Atlas is a text I was devoted to from the beginning. Mitchell's level of genIn what surely amounts to be the best book I've read in many years, Cloud Atlas is a text I was devoted to from the beginning. Mitchell's level of genius is so stout that I literally had to stop reading at every meta-fictitious turn, only to be coerced back to the text with lingering ideas, questions, and enthusiasm. The novel is written well, and that's what matters most. For lovers of books, perhaps a variety of genres of books, Mitchell dons varied hats: from journal entries, to epistolary fragments, to corny detective fiction, to sci-fi; the very different writing styles all seem authentic, and all seem Mitchell. His voice resounds in them all.For the literary scholar, Mitchell is everywhere. Ideas of Postcolonialism, Marxism (Socialism), Feminism, Minority/Gender/Queer Theory, Corporate Capitalism Criticism, etc. are featured; it's as if we're reading a PhD dissertation without the pretentious seven-syllable verbosity. Though the stories are loosely linked, they can almost be considered by themselves (my favorite was “Letters”). Common themes seem to include the value of text: how texts themselves translate to human connection over space and time (for the sake of this , I define text as book, music, film). Text is, in a sense, an extension of language, which is the vehicle of communication. Mitchell senses this, and uses it as his major theme: human connection. The narrators all have a metaphysical conceptual connection (reincarnation) but what's more here is how humans relate to one another in our shared...atlas. The ending of the novel, in its beautiful albeit socialist discourse, exemplifies this.Societies lusting over power over the rights of the individual will destroy themselves. It's socialism, buddhism, judeo-christian, liberal, basic-obvious-right-in-front-of-your-eyes-if-you'll-open-them-to-see humanism.There are so many isms, I wouldn't know where to start. How about with rereading the book? How about teaching it? How about simply celebrating a contemporary post-modern text that is its own puzzle box of self-referential philosophy, entertaining as much as it instructs?...more

review: Dr. Jekyll is a classic gothic theorist: there are components of good and evil in every human spirit. Though always the chemist, he believes he can isDr. Jekyll is a classic gothic theorist: there are components of good and evil in every human spirit. Though always the chemist, he believes he can isolate each through potions that rapidly change color (see: mom, food-coloring, water trick). Then, well, I don't know why I'd put it here. I could type the entire book over and it wouldn't even be a spoiler alert. Everyone knows what happens.What I found interesting was that Jekyll DECIDED to become Hyde over and over again, suggesting that Stevenson believed man's evil nature was more in correlation to his desires. To boot, Hyde goes out to perform ambiguous debaucheries (for stuffy England, probably beer and sex! Hyde, the frat monster!!) that Jekyll, in his elevated status, desires but could never commit out of propriety. This emphasizes the social class break between the exuberantly wealthy and the drunken nymphos of the proletariat. Or, does Stevenson suggest the lower classes' sins are the true needs (chemically/innately) of the human race and that the rich are really just rich in masking their needs?LL Cool J said it best: "Doin it and Doin it and Doin it well." review: This elegant collection of the poet's work takes us from his early, idealistic times, to his final days and mortally aware literature. Yeats's poetry This elegant collection of the poet's work takes us from his early, idealistic times, to his final days and mortally aware literature. Yeats's poetry is hyper-representative of Ireland, oftentimes exhibiting anthropomorphic figures of the country in his tale-like sing-song rhyming structures and poetic plots. Interspersed throughout, though, are his heavy Irish revolutionary thoughts, his lover's laments (damn you, Maude Gonne), and his pensive final summation of life and art.There are some truly deep and beautiful poems in this collection, enough to make you read again and again. The four plays, included throughout, likewise mirror Yeats's fascination with Irish politics, literature and lore, and love.Perhaps Ireland's greatest poet (and THAT is a distinction), a collection of Yeats should be on every shelf....more

title: The Corrections
author: Franzen, Jonathan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Corrections is a long contemporary novel in a time when long contemporary novels have become dino-tarpit. I was taken by Franzen's prose style froThe Corrections is a long contemporary novel in a time when long contemporary novels have become dino-tarpit. I was taken by Franzen's prose style from the onset, and swam relatively quickly through this thick work. At its heart, The Corrections is a critique on Americana (not to be confused with anti-patriotism, but the sort of Americana that causes Americans to take an introspective look at themselves in relationship to their culture and perhaps criticize the system to which they belong). Franzen's constant crosshairs seem to be on family and the hegemonic approbation of one's life into the family paradigm. Franzen examines how children "correct" the faults they find in their patriarchs in themselves, and finds that those "corrections" are what prompt progeny to make similar mistakes. Franzen's language is humorous, smart, often sad, and often brutal; but he has a well-read scholar's tone. This is mostly beneficial to the novel, but often has that pretentious academic flair of many post-modern novels that makes most of us cringe. Still, it's not enough to hurt the book too much.It seems Franzen is a little bereft of the feminine in the novel; the two female protagonists (see particularly: Denise) have relentless masculine qualities. Denise is bi-sexual, hyper-sexual, dominant, and successful. This isn't to say a woman cannot violate the prescribed gender roles of their sex, but is somewhat indicative that Franzen ascribes masculine gender roles in his female characters out of a possible disconnect with women in general. (It should be noted that as a man, this ain't no big thang. Most men fail at this, right brothers?). In general, this is a very masculine novel. Wrought with sex, wrought with violence: it tips the scales toward testosterone.The Corrections's characters are all very strong. Though flawed, each garners the reader's rooting, each has tender and redeemable qualities. Each exhibit the very human yin and yang that prevents readers from admonishing or canonizing any wholesale. Franzen doesn’t necessarily wrestle with the reader’s emotions, but he portrays characters as cautionary examples, which makes the novel a necessary and pleasant read. ...more

There are enough good sections throughout to understand Darwin's popularity and feasibility.What is more interesting is how ideas of Social Darwinism have surfaced from his very scientific studies. Through his arguments of Natural Selection and the perfection of descendent species, people could easily excuse colonization and imperialism (Darwin was, after all, a Brit). That isn't to say Darwin himself postulated the massacre of foreign culture was a more "perfect" nation's right, but one can see how his theories were augmented to satisfy such immoralities.Also, for all of you Jesus fish or Jesus fish-with-feet or Jesus fish-eating-Darwin fish car ornament knuckleheads out there, read the conclusion. title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's obviously very interesting to read about Socialism from the perspective of the 16th century. This reminds me of Bellamy's Looking Backward, whichIt's obviously very interesting to read about Socialism from the perspective of the 16th century. This reminds me of Bellamy's Looking Backward, which obviously took a lot of ideas from More's book. I rate it so low only because it's not very pleasant to read: a social commentary in Middle English=brain fatigue. Still, it's an important text. What More suggests is reflective of our society even today: that penal punishments do not prevent crime, which in and of itself is a result of the inequity of wealth in our society, etc. More's goal seems to be to suggest a perfect socialist state but in doing so, makes the glaring mistakes that Bellamy would three centuries later. In short, Utopia eliminates free will and champions conformity, which is contrary to human nature (at least in part). I'm down with the dissipation of all money and the social equity, but how More goes about producing an example of absolute socialism obviously delivers the sardonic intonation of our common usage of "utopia."Interestingly, More himself seems to presume it wouldn't work, having his own literary self doubt the feasibility of that society. It falls short very often in philosophy (More couldn't hide his own religious prejudices here to save his savior's life) but is hopeful in its humanity....more

review: Though not as remarkable as his later works, This Side of Paradise is a novel of astute observations into common aspects of life described in ways mosThough not as remarkable as his later works, This Side of Paradise is a novel of astute observations into common aspects of life described in ways most readers would have considered unthought-of. Fitzgerald has the uncanny ability to be witty, observant, and uniquely descriptive at once. Following in the vein of Joyce's Portrait of an Artist (published only 4 years before) and to be followed by Hemingway's The Sun Also Rises (only a few years after), Fitzgerald opines on the age-old Lost Generation problem: to be an egotistical youth interested only in making one's stamp on the world and finding that egoism problematic in a Post-war world that seems to care less and less about anyone's particular stamps (I'm finding, in my reading, this to be a decidedly masculine enterprise, especially for authors of first novels; I'll have to read some female authors of the era to get a complete view).Amory Blaine is born of wealth, loses it, and becomes a sort of socialist toward the end. Throughout are the common perturbances of youth: young ridiculous love, college days, benders, and a whole ship's hull of regret. Though Amory seems to find self-peace in is oscillating demeanor, I reckon that if there were a next chapter, he'd be somewhere near bottom again. How common to the common stamps of we who leave youth for the next great folly: middle age....more

review: I cannot say I was passionately pleased at reading this autobiography, though it has some obvious merits. Being a Philadelphian, I did take great inteI cannot say I was passionately pleased at reading this autobiography, though it has some obvious merits. Being a Philadelphian, I did take great interest in Franklin's walking the city (present day the Old City neighborhood) and his movements and activities therein. There were also interesting bits of humor and history woven throughout, showing the beginnings of American Literature and the foundings of his concepts of "virtue." I especially liked his opinions on vegetarianism: when battling his previous inclination to the discipline, he had placed in front of him a fish. In examining the stomach of the fish, found smaller fish, concluding that if a creature eats another creature, he shall eat it.I'm going to use this with all my militant vegan friends.I appreciated Franklin's desire for personal betterment through reading and writing and the pursuit of multi-lingual fluidness.Still, he is often racist, particularly to Native Americans ("And indeed if it be the design of Providence to extirpate these savages in order to make room for cultivators of the Earth, it seems not improbable that rum may be the appointed means. It has already annihilated all of the tribes who formally inhabited the seacoast.") and though he claims humility, seems arrogant as all get out.The end of the book is a chore, often boring and detailing all of the wonderful things he's done. It's a valuable book to read for history's sake, but oh so taxing (get it? Taxing?)....more

review: A splendid personal novel about the progression of a young artist's mind from its moocow childhood to its sophisticated, often numbingly academic younA splendid personal novel about the progression of a young artist's mind from its moocow childhood to its sophisticated, often numbingly academic young adulthood.Each chapter progresses young Stephen Dedalus in age, from his early youth of insecurity and timidness winning over his comrades with a victory against the clerical establishment, to a young man experiencing sexual curiosity as it conflicts with religious piety, to a Brothel John, to a repentant sinner a hair away from priesthood, to an academic man of letters theorizing Aquinas and God.Special insight is given here to the development of artistic thought and how those individuals for whom art has spoken go on to develop their craft. Also included are lofty sermons from hell-blazing pastors that show the reader the insidious fear mongering of the church in rural Ireland and how much said church played a role in Ireland's North-South division and Independence from Jolly Olde.The latter sections are like chewing chalk, what with their lofty philosophy; but if anyone ever came to a Joyce book expecting to wholesale understand every word, you sir are a better man than I....more

title: Great Expectations
author: Dickens, Charles
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I began my journey with Dickens's large book in Clark Park, Philadelphia, which I hear is the only park in the world that has a Dickens statue. WhetheI began my journey with Dickens's large book in Clark Park, Philadelphia, which I hear is the only park in the world that has a Dickens statue. Whether or not this melodrama is true, I thought it fitting...because I'm melodramatic.Dickens has the wonderful ability to make you look silly, laughing out loud in public places like libraries or coffeeshops, where everyone else is trying to be serious. I found at least half the sentences of this book to be smart funny; not pretentious funny (see Salmon Rushdie, late-night political pundits, all of your professors from all time) but smart and funny. Dickens was educated and he doesn't pretend not to be.The soul of this story has to do with social class and ideas of elevations inside of one's personal situation. The titular Pip, whose name even suggests something puny or subjugated, feels his personal human worth in comparison to those around him at a higher social or economic status. When he achieves a bit of status himself, he quickly tramples upon those who'd always supported him as members of society champion his status over his person. Later, when Pip learns the dubious source of his financial winnings (and dire straits concerning them), he goes though the moral withdraw that accompanies the vacuum of want in a capitalistic society. What I think makes this book so appealing is that contemporary audiences will recognize Pip's desire to better himself as a sociological characteristic of perhaps all of us. We are taught to be idle is to be evil, that it is only through betterment (financial, academic, experiential) will our lives be vindicated, as if we need a validation for being alive.These issues are evidenced in Pip's faulty delusion of grandeur concerning Estelle and the way the court system of England chooses its verdicts according to the parties' dress. Couple these observations with an interesting and complex plot about jilted love, revenge on MANkind, greed, and social deviance, and you have Great Expectations indeed.Minus the melodrama....more

The sheer scope of Tolkien's fantastical kingdom and lore are enough to warrant such a positive .That saying, the final book wraps things up nicely. So much so, that I didn't mind the ending coming 50 pages before the book's close. Holy-extended-epilogue Tolkien. I liked the ending, with its sentimentality and finite tied ends.All things considered, The Lord of the Rings has earned its place in the literary canon. title: Paradise Lost
author: Milton, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Milton's poetic narrative, telling of the background events leading up to the creation and fall of Adam and Eve, is a pleasure to read. In his own conMilton's poetic narrative, telling of the background events leading up to the creation and fall of Adam and Eve, is a pleasure to read. In his own conceptual justification of the "ways of God to man," Milton elaborates where the Bible is general, and anthropomorphizes the characters of Judeo-Christian drama.I am most intrigued by the first four chapters, where the focus is Satan, who laments with his minions his first and more fierce fall. Though Milton comes close to preachy in the text, he never outright lambasts Satan. Rather, it is interesting the way Milton anthropomorphizes the fallen angels, including Satan, giving them humanesque ideas and sentimentalities. The reader develops almost a pity for them as they realize their error but find repentance too late and distant. As humans ourselves, we recognize immediately personal mistakes, egoism, and burnt bridges that we expect God or life itself to forgive us for, yet these fallen angels are without hope of forgiveness. The reader feels sorry for them. Satan is condemned to Hell for his “pride” and “worse, ambition,” while Adam and Eve, the poem's protagonists, seem nubile and foolish throughout. All of this reinforces the mysteries of biblical mythology, hardly illuminating them.The middle chapters and final two (which were not of the original poem) were drab, but worth it overall. Enter misogyny, Eve is the scapegoat of the entire race. Chick can't catch a break, even with Milton.Was cool to see famous book titles come from the poem: East of Eden (Hemingway), In Dubious Battle (Steinbeck)....more

title: Robinson Crusoe
author: Defoe, Daniel
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's good to know that if anything bad happened, and I mean ANYTHING, I'd be set to live effectively with divine providence forever all because I readIt's good to know that if anything bad happened, and I mean ANYTHING, I'd be set to live effectively with divine providence forever all because I read this epic tutorial on how to be uncommonly lucky and outrageously capable.Forgive me, but I thought Crusoe was a bit of a dunce. I mean, we start out with a very common and on-the-point depiction of a young man wanting to make his way understanding the world, then are thrust into his castaway life while he makes bread, fashions canoes out of trees and fortifies a castle. If his name was Richard Dean Anderson, I might buy it. But Robinson Crusoe? Throughout the narrative, the protag himself doubts everything he does, is hyper-phobic, and seems to occasion his successes by accident.I don't know if Defoe was creating satire here, but my gut says no (that was what Swift was for); so then, we have unrealistic happenstance that we are supposed to finally understand as God's willingness to spare His sinful creatures. aka. there are grapes on an island you get stranded on when you disobey your father's desire that you be a lawyer and instead travel (and this is why Catholic guilt always hit home with me). And can we just say that this novel maintains the most outrageous ignorance toward other cultures: Crusoe finds no fault in going to Africa to get slaves (in fact, he never considers God shipwrecked him because of this), and the "savages" on the island are fearful inhumane cannibals who it is righteous to kill because God would probably smite them anyway.Blatant racism aside (if that's possible), if you liked the Boxcar Children growing up (Divine Providence knows I did), then you'll enjoy this grown-up version....more

author: Swift, Jonathan

review: I, like most of my fellow Yahoos, understood only a small portion of Gulliver's aforementioned travels: the giant, tied with ropes by miniscule versioI, like most of my fellow Yahoos, understood only a small portion of Gulliver's aforementioned travels: the giant, tied with ropes by miniscule versions of itself, pincushioned with arrows and forced to parlay with his captors. When I finally developed the virtue of a horse, I read the entire manuscript, and feel like now making up a lot of gaelic sounding words.Blargordrib hmlarktomally srowntom hrhrhrhmitor.Which, roughly translated in my negligent English means: Jonathan Swift, the Yahoo, speaks in the things that aren't real, and is funny.The book gets funnier as it moves forward; the funniest part suggesting that immortal creatures are forced only to marry for about 80 years, because living forever seems punishment enough to not have to also bear the weight of a wife. Or perhaps it was pissing out a fire and getting the death penalty for it that was funniest. No matter; what Swift does is put his constantly ill-fortuned protagonist (seriously, how may times would you take to sea if you kept finding nothing but calamity?) in unique satirical situations to illustrate our human flaws and discrepancies in virtue. When we are the biggest we are revered and threatening; the smallest, a sideshow, a primate to sophistication, and completely ignorant to other cultures. The narrative is dry, but I reckon this was the style of the 18th century and the entertainments therein, so I won't complain too much.Thesis: Swift hated lawyers, noble folk, and royalty, but loved the humble and honest....more

title: It
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ok, so how come none of the characters realized they were dealing with a Boggart and used the Rediculus spell on it? Didn't they see Harry Potter and Ok, so how come none of the characters realized they were dealing with a Boggart and used the Rediculus spell on it? Didn't they see Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban?Stephen King is a hell of a story-teller and an awful writer. I mean, literally, there were times in this book when I wanted to rip out pages, they were ruining it so much (SPOILER: when young--12-year-old--Beverly feels the only way they'll find their way out of the tunnel after vanquishing Pennywise for the first time is to screw all of the 12 year-old-boys in succession. . .um? Right.) There was real horror in the writing itself. Strangely, however, there was some real beauty too. Every once in a while, King wrote interesting (though often melodramatic) passages or chapters about love and friendship that really hit home.I liked reading the book. For a 1138 page novel, I read it pretty quickly, and liked the journey of it. King is imaginative, and if you can get passed the juvenile writing, you get a pretty decent story of what home means to people, how we often leave home, and the ramifications of finding ourselves in relation to re-examining our birthplaces. Pennywise represents the fear that comes latent with admitting your home is where your heart is (King would say, "where the heart was, which upon getting a scratch, bled buckets for infinity, and was like a Red Sox game.")But really, everyone in the book laughs too much and laughs inappropriately, when a real human being would NOT laugh. Sometimes King’s over sexualization of female characters and use of sexual description to describe innocuous things was teenage. And when you find the metaphysical/mystical characters of the text (IT and a Turtle, yeah) they talk like teenage skateboarders, like the rest of King's characters.There's a reason King is the best-selling author of all time but will never be a classic writer. The proof is in the pudding. A-yuh....more

title: Moby-Dick or, The Whale
author: Melville, Herman
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The sense of accomplishment one feels at completing a bear of a masterpiece leaves me high upon crests of waves.If I were Ishmael, I would now spend tThe sense of accomplishment one feels at completing a bear of a masterpiece leaves me high upon crests of waves.If I were Ishmael, I would now spend the next 400 pages dissecting senses of accomplishment, bears (the animal, its origins and various species), masterpieces, and waves. I would start with etymologies and end with sentimental pinings and anecdotes. I would drive most of you away.I was in love with the first 100 pages, where Ishmael's voice is truly his own, and where Melville's absolute wit forced me to put the book down and chuckle page upon page in succession. Mind you, these first 100 pages are before Ishmael even boards the Pequod and takes to ocean. Then, many things happen over the course of the next 400 pages that distract the reader from realizing that nothing is happening over the next 400 pages. Look, I knew, coming into this, that Moby Dick wasn't going to be a big plot story. I realized we might not ever even see the white whale (we do....with 60 pages to go!) long before picking the book up. But what happens is through most of it, Ishmael spends encyclopedic chapters numbing the reader into learned submission. He annuls the variety of whales, the color white, the processes of sailing and whale capture; etc. At times, the book reads like a graduate class in cetology rather than a novel. Many of my friends and contemporaries put the book down, or bemoan it, for this. But let's look at why Melville does it.I'm giving Herman the benefit of the doubt. After reading stories like Bartleby, we know he is purposeful in his actions. But is Melville doing the Joycean "I'm screwing with my readers" thing? I think, in part. Bottom line: this novel is about one man's dark obsession (referred to as monomania) and how it affects the lives of those in the periphery of that obsession. It is largely a philosophical text, told through the yarn of sea-story, examining man's place in the Universe and the "reality" of God. Got that? Ok. So why, then, all the pragmatic instructional videos? (ed. note: I'd like to pause and say I really did learn how to catch a whale at sea; time will tell if I'll ever need this skill). What I think Melville is doing is, by Ishmael's obsessing of the menial details of the novel, the reader gets the impression of how deeply rooted Ahab's obsession truly is. In short, we have to be almost obsessed with finishing this novel in order to finish it. Moreover, we learn that Melville, as an extension of Ishmael, must be obsessed with this novel to write such a painstaking tome (we know he intended it to be is masterpiece). He was obsessed with the novel, Ahab was obsessed with the whale, Ishmael was obsessed with telling the readers the details, the reader is obsessed with finishing the tale. The point remains the same: obsession. And the reader, unless wedded to stories tied tight with bows, is the only of the aforementioned quotients to leave the process unscathed. Even Melville himself died in obscurity over the public failure of his obsession, the book.Also, a whaleboat, despite the random excitements, must be a boring place, allowing Ishmael to ruminate on such seemingly petty additions. I think Melville cleverly insinuated the "downtime" of whaling by making us readers feel we were in a constant downtime while reading. One literary violation Melville commits, that I cannot wholly forgive, is that Ishmael, after those first 100 pages, loses his voice. The book starts as a first person narrative than moves to omniscient perspectives of various characters without maintaining Ishmael’s early witty voice. Melville, seemingly for lack of a better idea, just abandons Ishmael, in favor of telling the story from almost a third person perspective. This is a big no-no in my book. Ishmael’s early voice was the best part.White whales, the Holy Grail, or verbose tomes, we all have focuses; Moby Dick is the cautionary tale of how our focuses may blind our peripheral instincts....more

title: Islands in the Stream
author: Hemingway, Ernest
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: For anyone who would venture upon this novel as their first trip into Hemingway, I'd presume a rating of far less celestial body. The reality is, thisFor anyone who would venture upon this novel as their first trip into Hemingway, I'd presume a rating of far less celestial body. The reality is, this posthumously published, three-part story is not Hemingway's best. In fact, the novel has some pretty uncharacteristic flaws. It is full of the very traditional Hemingway: startling one-liners, little plot with heavy emotion and warmth, intense scene recognition and spatial consideration, machismo oozing out the ears. You name it.But, for the Hemingway aficionado, this book is a keen look not into the end of a great's bibliography, but into the great himself. It is a Roman a clef, like all of his other novels, essentially. Hemingway only ever wrote about himself, which I don't think was an effort of egoism as much as it was an effort to write honestly; and how does one write completely honestly?, by writing about what one knows the best (presumably): himself.And no one loves Hemingway's plots. I mean, how could you? 500 pages to blow up one bridge? Liver psoriasis bullfight? Old man fishing? Quitting the army with a nurse? Plots are nothing to Hemingway. What we love is the coursing energy of honesty flowing directly and forcibly through the text. We breathe truth and cringe at its brutality. Joy at its beauty.Then you get Islands in the Stream: a lie.The first section, Bimini, is the best, far and away (ignore the 100 page fish fight). Here we have classic and dependable Hemingway, now typified through a painter, Thomas Hudson, while his sons visit from their jilted mothers, Hem's wake. The story is nostalgic, poignant, and laced with morosity, which, if you know anything about Hemingway the man, was also the end of his life. He lamented Hadley, his failed fathership, and a writing career that was less and less appreciated. Thomas Hudson in Bimini was this: truthfully and honestly.Then, between the end of Bimini and the beginning of Cuba, all three of his sons die, which is not true to life. Rather, it sort of sets the reader to feel more sorry for Hudson (nee Hemingway), who is now a sad alcoholic creature. He really wants us to pity him! Never before have I felt the need to pity Hemingway's amorphisms, not even while dying, or not getting Brett, or having your lady die during childbirth. Was sad, but never pitied. Hudson is pitiful.Then, out of nowhere, Hadley Hemingway comes along. Now, we all know that Hadley remarried after Hem and happily lived out the rest of her days. We also know that she was a homely, not flashy sorta gal (read A Paris Wife for a good depiction). In this novel, she makes an appearance in Havana and is a ... wait for it ... movie starlet!?, who can't resist Hudson and makes love to him while blaming HERSELF for the dissolution of their marriage (a plot problem because earlier Hudson claimed he left her). I mean, the audacity of Hemingway to make Hadley into a sluttish starlet to vindicate his own evils.So of course, in good conscience, he kills Hudson.Very flawed and very dishonest. It gets four from me because I loved how much it showed me about Hemingway's personal instability at the end of his life. And I don't fault him anything; after all, he never tried to publish this book: that was for the vultures post-mortem. Vultures I'm thankful for....more

title: Emma

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: With all due respect and a consciousness as to why Austen is beloved, I get a bit yawny with romance. If I had a match.com profile, it would say: I LOWith all due respect and a consciousness as to why Austen is beloved, I get a bit yawny with romance. If I had a match.com profile, it would say: I LOVE walks on the beach and picnics with my special lady. Red wine? Yellow tail? You betcha. Totally laid back, love Nicholas Sparks and the movies adapted from his gems featuring that same square-jawed actor. Message me to chat!And so on.But it would be BS. And I don't have a match.com profile. But this is basically what Emma is about.The characterizations are interesting: hypochondriac father, spoiled pretentious rich girl, old money gentry v. new money snobs, trust fund babies, general boring lives. Still, I hated the protagonist, Emma, for being so blatantly horrible and I do not think she was redeemed at the end, despite that being Jane Austen's potential ideal. Austen seems to stab into the tragic class system and superiority complexes of the gentry, but ultimately vindicates them (Emma, of course, marrying the most gentlemanly gentleman of all gentlemen, with the richest estate and highest propriety, ad barfeam.)One interesting thing that Austen does in her writing is she has the readers know what the plot twists well be before her characters know. Never was I nearly as surprised as her characters. In fact, the book was generally predictable...which I do not subtract praise for, as it seemed intentional.Oh, and Wikipedia told me the movie Clueless was based on it. title: Nemesis
author: Roth, Philip
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "But there's nobody less salvageable than a ruined good boy."Roth's short novella about the polio scares of WWII in American cities claims as its focu"But there's nobody less salvageable than a ruined good boy."Roth's short novella about the polio scares of WWII in American cities claims as its focus a discourse on fear, responsibility, duty, and the tragedy that is happenstance.Roth's protagonist, Mr. Cantor, is incapable of separating himself from his sense of duty and responsibility. What Roth then does is show a contrast in these two phenomena through the situations Cantor finds himself in. As a phys ed teacher and playground superintendent, his duty and responsibility elevate him to the social archetype of heroic shepherd of children. Later, as a polio sufferer and potential Outbreak Monkey to the children that were his charge, his duty and responsibility result in self-chastisement. Cantor blames God in the obligatory way that those of religious backgrounds make sense of the unpredictable cruelty of the Universe. He is a tragic character that was once a hero, fallen not because of dubious act, but because he could not himself reconcile the happenstance that every man is victim to with his own destiny.Roth is often a bit redundant and the narration of the book was very strange and at first bothered me: a child from Cantor's playground gang who remained removed from the story until the very end, delivering an Ayn Rand-esque final soliloquy on the moral of the story. Still, as I muse on it, that final chapter did bump my three stars to four, so I suppose I eventually made my peace with it.If only Cantor could have....more

title: Uncle Tom’s Cabin
author: Stowe, Harriet Beecher
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Though not necessarily the most innovatively written book, and certainly of the more (as popular critics have noted) sentimental genres, Uncle Tom's CThough not necessarily the most innovatively written book, and certainly of the more (as popular critics have noted) sentimental genres, Uncle Tom's Cabin is a book that, for me, illustrates the social and moral effects literature has on responsible readers.Like most who encounter a "Classic" novel, I entered my reading with certain comprehensions of the novel and its characters, namely the epithet "Uncle Tom" given to African Americans who are servile and accommodating to "white" society. What I found in my study was more a literary rhetoric on emancipation that mirrored some of the famous abolitionist publications in the American Literary tradition: see Phyllis Wheatley and Frederick Douglass.Stowe made no suggestion that her novel was anything outside of a propaganda piece against slavery, and its wide popularity shows that the American public was (at least at that time) open to perspectives illuminated by literature.I do understand more modern ideas of antagonism to the novel: black stereotypes, etc; but I harken back to Stowe's intention and the change of ideology that this novel inspired. Like all abolitionist literature, the goal was to humanize the African slave so that moral and religious people could not justify the insidious nature of slavery. Thomas Jefferson, in his "Notes of the State of Virginia" goes as far as to conclude that the African race is biologically different than whites and resemble characteristics of an "Oranootan [Orangutan]." To counter these animalistic comparisons, abolitionists published the likes of Wheatley and Douglass to show the African races ability for intellectualism and to produce poetry, leading people to thusly conclude that they were in fact human, and ready for equal rights.Stowe's novel is of the same vein. Written just before the Civil War, she smartly chooses to present Christian values (of great rhetorical use in the mid-19th century) and motherly affection for children to garner just the same empathy as the other abolitionist writers. Although there may be a lot to criticize the novel with, and although it certainly follows an expected structure of rhetoric, I respect the book greatly as a prime example of responsible literature's value to society and the sympathies of mankind, who absorbs it in its relative sensibilities....more

title: The Paris Wife
author: McLain, Paula*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A Paris Wife is a charming and emotional new perspective into the life of one of America’s greatest literary heroes during a time that most (Owen WilsA Paris Wife is a charming and emotional new perspective into the life of one of America’s greatest literary heroes during a time that most (Owen Wilson most recently) of the literarily inclined would have loved to live and see: the lost expatriate Parisian 1920s with Hemingway.What makes Mclain’s account so beautiful is that it draws on what we know about the times to construct the narrative. It’s fiction, as much as the book jacket says it is, but she uses not just Papa’s works, but those of Pound, Fitzgerald, Stein, and others to illuminate the situations her protagonist, Hadley, is perceiving. For those who’ve read the histories and fictions of these people, most scenes and scenarios will be recycled for you. But one of the best qualities of the work is that all the stories (particularly A Moveable Feast) are retold through Hadley’s eyes, which presents us with emotion and personhood that Hemingway’s bravado is so often devoid of. We emote with Hemingway because of the situations he puts us in. We emote with Hadley because she makes us see her tragedy. We live it with her. And knowing what we do about Hemingway: that he regretted his disintegration with Hadley and ultimately killed himself due to this, among other unfulfillments and mental illnesses; helps us believe her story, even if it is fictitious.Basically, the book is beautiful. It belongs with all of the other stories and biographies of the Lost. There’s such playfulness, luminescence into these lives, and longing to understand greatness as it touches the fringes of normalcy. Ultimately, though, I view it as a cautionary tale: Hemingway chose his work and impulses over Hadley, but those in the know would bet it all that he would have traded it to go back and not make his mistakes, greatness be damned. No one gets to go back, but this novel gives us a bit of foresight into how we might make it to not want to....more

title: Henderson the Rain King
author: Bellow, Saul
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: At the 2011 AWP Conference in DC, I went to a panel where very clever folks of the literati rejudged the 1960 National Book Award. They deliberated, bAt the 2011 AWP Conference in DC, I went to a panel where very clever folks of the literati rejudged the 1960 National Book Award. They deliberated, by reading and assessing all of the novels nominated for the prize that year (and offering outsiders), and overruled the Roth novel originally picked with Henderson the Rain King (as if Bellow needed any more National Book Awards, Pulitzers, or Nobels). Now, I haven't read the Roth book, so I cannot engage in the discourse, though I think the panel was more about how taste and perception of (literary) art ages as do the books themselves.I can, however, assess this novel. Expanding from the very common Zeitgeist of Americana concerning fear of death with the directionlessness of life, Bellow casts his protagonist into savage and bizarre Africa, to find...ready for it...meaning.As hokey as that all sounds, Bellow makes a sort of satire out of the whole thing. The protagoinst is very flawed, but knows it, and his bumbles through Africa, often from viewing Africans as messianic pets in a zoo, create a cartoonish effect. Case in point, note how many metaphors Henderson offers for his own face. The entire plot is somewhat slapstick, but makes us invest in Henderson and his folly.Despite this caricature of travel and life-experience, Bellow touches on such subtle and wonderful oddities of the human spirit: imagination, the acceptance/rejection of reality, desire, and fulfillment. We don't ever grab Henderson by the collar and shout, "By George, you've got it," but we respect his search, as maniachal and egocentric as it is. This is, of course, parallel to our own little solopsistic glimmer of dramatic reality....more

Perhaps this is a lesson for my future students in and of itself.Burroughs's relationship with his father, although tempered through the window of his own memory and perspective, it downright poison to read. For anyone who thought they had a sour relationship with their father, this book will set you staight: your papa was great. I can't help but feel that some of it was invention, but as a strict work of literature, Burroughs makes his point: that there is no substitute for parental love, that we can ruin each other if we're not careful, and that sperm is only one (and maybe even the least valuable) part of fatherhood....more

title: Reading Lolita in Tehran: A Memoir in Books
author: Nafisi, Azar*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ironically, or perhaps as an admission to the lack of "Na" authors on my shelves, Nafisi's memoir sits next to Nabokov's Lolita. I appreciate the mystIronically, or perhaps as an admission to the lack of "Na" authors on my shelves, Nafisi's memoir sits next to Nabokov's Lolita. I appreciate the mystical literary happenstance as I am sure both aforementioned authors would as well.Reading Lolita in Tehran is a multi-tiered book. On one level, it is a novel about women's rights in a place where those words are equivalent to sin and breaking the law. Secondly, it is an academic text, with analyses of popular Western literature that come from someone intensely passionate about the works. And finally, it is one woman's--one teacher's--memoir about subjugation, violence, and the horror of a totalitarian regime in the Islamic Republic of Iran.What I appreciated most about this book was how much I learned about Iranian culture and the evolution of what we now consider modern-day Iran. This part of the world is very foreign from the West, particularly Americans, and Nafisi does a wonderful job making it accessible. I began, while reading, to understand yet again how these folks, some of whom consider Americans to be brutal enemies, have more in common with Americans than they'd perhaps like to admit.Nafisi, though at times masculigist (I made this up!!!!) and often pessimistic about love, exhibits a tenderness for her students that any teacher can respect and wish to emulate. Furthermore and finally, she exposes us to horrors through the lens of tenderness and a love of literature. If you're reading this on Goodreads, then you get it....more

title: Looking Backward: 2000-1887
author: Bellamy, Edward
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: As an intellectual exercise I found this book to be very engaging and interesting. If you are excited by books that make you think, or attempt to drawAs an intellectual exercise I found this book to be very engaging and interesting. If you are excited by books that make you think, or attempt to draw you into open-minded perspectives, than I quickly refer you to this book, as it is slim, quick, and at least engaging.Although the idea of Mr. West's time travel is rather comical (who hasn't fallen asleep for 100 years?) and although I kept waiting for him to deteriorate like Mel Gibson in Forever Young, the actual movement of plot was at first fun. In my view, the best parts were West's discourses on individuality and the self, when tampered with by striking one's own environment. What becomes of a person when we distort the context of the person?As most know, this is less a novel and more philosophical rhetoric on socialism. If we understand this, then we can forgive the poor narrative devices in favor of the propaganda. Still, the middle section of the book is largely pages upon pages of esoteric talk that makes you wish you read faster. As to Bellamy's Socialism itself, let me be the first to say that I am humanly in love with ideas of social equity, proper education systems, and the dissolution of class warfare and poverity, but Bellamy's utopia is just that, a utopia. And based on human experience, we know that utopias are fictions. What's more, the deeper you get into the text, the more you begin to see Bellamy's (nee socialism's) ignorance concerning Darwinism (if you so believe that), independence, constitutional US rights, and basic human morality. To boot, within are laced old fashioned ideas of homophobia, sexism, and religious intolerance. The individual is completely sacraficed to the system in a way more frightening than in 1984 and Bellamy goes as far as to suggest that there is no jealousy or crime any longer because of social parity (!!!). It's strange to me that he would suggest human nature is a result of the system. In my view, as it was built by humans, the system would be better described as a result of human nature. Case in point, Bellamy asserts through his characters that it was "natural" that man would "evolve" into the modern system of socialism by the year 2000 because that was their natural inclination. Update: it's 2011, and he was wrong. Not very natural after all.He's also very critical of other ages. I have an intolerance for intolerance. So, good read for thinking, but it irked my time and again how off the author was in his own theories, no matter how noble they were in the pondering....more

title: Geek Love
author: Dunn, Katherine
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Perhaps one of the most disturbing books I've read, Geek Love kept me fascinated from the first turn of the page through the last heartbreaking word. Perhaps one of the most disturbing books I've read, Geek Love kept me fascinated from the first turn of the page through the last heartbreaking word. At the surface, the novel is a telescopic view into a Carny family of "freaks" (quotation marks used purposefully and with added-added stress here) who degenerate over time as the megalomaniacal eldest brother (Aquaboy) generates a legion of amputee cult followers and a series of rather disgusting (albeit completely pleasing, in the "Exorcist scares the bejesus out of me but I watch it every time it comes on" sort of way) events that make up this wacky mythology.In the present tense, our narrator, hunchback albino dwarf Oly, sits nude for her artist daughter and plans murder.And I never thought I'd sum a novel in that fashion.And that's just the surface. Underlying are discourses on love, affection, familial struggle/rivalry, capitalism, and the empty loneliness of individualism. Mostly, however, the book is a satire. When the freak family (bred from heavy doses of drugs in utero) has a "norm" child, the family laments, much in the way a "norm" family laments a "different" child. If we analyze the novel critically, we find many more observations about traditional values and routine life than we perhaps originally thought when looking at this seemingly foreign group of people. Breeding to sustain one's own legacy/capital, preferential treatment towards children that fulfill us, the debilitating disorder of ugliness (physical and non), etc. all make up what Dunn achieves in this multi-tiered novel.It's written beautifully: disturbing, coy, funny, challenging, and ultimately brilliant....more

title: The Town and the City
author: Kerouac, Jack
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In what I think I may consider to be Jack Kerouac's best work (indeed), we get a novel that transcends the Beat nomadic zeitgeist of a generation in fIn what I think I may consider to be Jack Kerouac's best work (indeed), we get a novel that transcends the Beat nomadic zeitgeist of a generation in favor of a very tender, very American, portrait of a bucolic American family as it morphs, changes, collapses, and triumphs (in not that order) over the years.I was refreshed by this novel page after page, enthused at the first turnings, in love with Kerouac's prose style, which is so flawless and tender. (Though seriously, the word "sad" appeared in this novel double the times the word "fuck" was in Pulp Fiction, or even perhaps all of Tar's films). The writing is constantly fluid, a departure from what I remember about Jack's most famous Duluoz legacy books, which are more disjointed and stream of consciousness. The events are still a Roman a Clef, with much from Kerouac's real life following Peter Martin very closely. I gathered, however, that many of the characters' personalities were alive in Kerouac. Joe: the mechanic romantic road warrior. Francis: the aloof intellectual; Martin: the sprite serious youngster; Liz: the jazz singing vagabond; etc. Kerouac seems to shatter his personality and delegate the pieces to his people.The novel is, not surprisingly, separated into two main chunks. The town. and the City. The town is Galloway, based directly on Kerouac's own home milltown of Lowell. This section of the book is by far the longest (3/5s) and has the most tender, beautiful and truly American portions. The lower-class bucolic country family, the detailed football games, the horse-betting, the Christmas mornings, the small-town bar hopping. I loved this section of the book because it was one of the first times I saw true American ideology shine through so perfectly in literature.The second substantially smaller section of the book is the city. NYC. Here, everything is compact, chaotic, poetic, and insane. This obviously shows Kerouac's feelings on the matter: i.e. The Town VS the City. I know Kerouac loved the metropolis, but the chaos of the city sections shows his despair that comes from being swallowed by it. Still, this section is written very much like a long poem and is an obvious precursor for On the Road, which comes next. The end of this book finds Peter about to hit the road, in much the same fashion that Jack himself was about to do. Seven years later, he would pen what would be the Bible of the Beats. I think an astute reader should back up one chapter in Jack's life and see how it all began.A sad but honest and beautiful big book....more
