title: Fury
author: Rushdie, Salman
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Having thoroughly enjoyed Midnight's Children, I was eager to sink my teeth into another Rushdie. This novel, however, makes me furious. Barf.Rushdie'Having thoroughly enjoyed Midnight's Children, I was eager to sink my teeth into another Rushdie. This novel, however, makes me furious. Barf.Rushdie's prose is very intelligent; actually, it's academically pretentious throughout, which is challenging to read and disengaging but in all honesty, fun to encounter. It's just that the academic tone really pulls the reader well out of caring for the characters and situations. The first chapter is extremely clever and overtly academic. After this, the novel subtly touches on the life of its protagonist, making him completely inapproachable to readers.I was also turned off by the dialogue. Every single character, regardless of cultural background, education, or class, speaks with the exact same unbelieveably pretentious discourse, which is, obviously, Rushdie's own voice. In short, it prevented me from giving a lickity split about any of these fools.Also, America. I get it: you're criticising American culture. And although there are some poignant responses to the more repulsive aspects of Americana (trust me, many of us Americans feel a great distaste for much of our [pop] culture) there is a overreaction and disorganization of the true concept of the country. It almost seems like Rushdie is basing his claims on prejudicial sterotypical complaints against America rather than concrete empiracal evidence. I would expect an educated and cultured writer to know better.There are some interesting plot developments, but they are generally unbelievable, outside the scope of the reasons for the story, and tend to go nowhere. The first chapter is academic ranting. The last chapter is decent poetic writing. Everything in between is something to shake our collective heads at....more

title: In the Garden of Beasts: Love, Terror, and an American Family in Hitler's Berlin
author: Larson, Erik*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I rather enjoy Erik Larson because he takes the usually mundane endeavor of writing historical non-fiction and makes it interesting. Devil in the WhitI rather enjoy Erik Larson because he takes the usually mundane endeavor of writing historical non-fiction and makes it interesting. Devil in the White City was a spectacular example of this; In the Garden of Beasts is not.Capitalizing off of the concept of telling parallel stories in the same setting as he did in DWC, Larson attempts the same trick in IGOB by telling the historic tale of Dodd as ambassador and the more literary romantic story of Martha (his daughter) as a Berlin harlot with possible KGB ties. What bothered me even more was the premonitory tone of impending doom that Larson laces into each section and chapter. I understand the tone he was trying to set: the Nazi usurping of Germany and impending war, but the foreshadowing he illustrates ends up being constantly redundant and histrionic. For example: (paraphrase) Dodd was usually such a great driver, it would be very ironic WHAT WOULD ULTIMATELY HAPPEN TO HIM!!!!!! This makes you believe he would eventually die in a Nazi organized car crash or something. No, twenty years later, back in the US, he hits a kid with his car.Another: (paraphrase) Martha loved Germany but on this trip she would SUDDENLY EXPERIENCE SOMETHING THAT WOULD FOREVER CHANGE HER INNOCUOUS VIEW OF THE COUNTRY AS THE TERRIBLE EVENTS SEWED THEMSELVES INTO HER VIRGINAL FLESH. Making you think that gestapo goons rape her and kill her lover or something only to find out she witnessed a Nazi beating.I'm not minimalizing the latter events; all I'm saying is that Larson really over-employs the technique of cliffhangerism.And the ending thumps down like an old boot.The only positive is that Larson effectively establishes what many contemporary Americans cannot fathom: how Germany, Europe, and the world allowed Hitler, the Holocaust, and WWII to happen. When you read the book, it seems obvious....more

title: Stay Out of the Basement        (Goosebumps, #2)
author: Stine, R.L.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is the first book I ever remember reading. I mean, I'm sure that my parents and grandparents read me stories as a yute, but the Goosebumps seriesThis is the first book I ever remember reading. I mean, I'm sure that my parents and grandparents read me stories as a yute, but the Goosebumps series is one I can remember choosing to read; this nuance is important.My copy of Stay Out of the Basement is with the original cover, a green very detailed hand coming out of the basement. This is the original edition from 1992, from when I was 10 years old. I have to say, the nostalgia of holding the same book I read almost 20 years ago is a high water mark for me. Moreover, I credit the Goosebumps books as what spurred my literary exploration, something that has enveloped the greater part of my life and career. So, R. L., I thank you.What's better is, after reading this book in a sitting, it's actually good. I mean, for youngsters, the book is well written, Stine does well to consider spacial needs of the reader (the scenes are well built and the environment is always considered), and the tension at the end of each chapter is legit.I remember being young, finishing a Goosebumps book, and waiting impatiently for a week for the next to come out. I remember rubbing the raised bumpy letters of the books on the car ride home. Then I remember the furious two hours of reading that left me waiting for another 7 days to pass. Good thing I later discovered Fear Street.Stay Out of the Basement, I owe you a big one, old friend....more

title: A Farewell to Arms
author: Hemingway, Ernest
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In rereading this just because, I was about halfway through when I realized I'd have to give a Hemingway novel less than five stars. The copy I have wIn rereading this just because, I was about halfway through when I realized I'd have to give a Hemingway novel less than five stars. The copy I have was bought at a bookstore in Stratford upon Avon, where I visited as a student studying in London a great many years ago, and a certain nostalgia packed with literary posterity thusly exists in the empirical book itself; however, I couldn't get over the fact that the book was very dull in comparison to his other great successes. I felt as if the tone was bland and displaced, and that the blossoming love between Frederick and Catherine was very contrived and unrealistic. (I think I vomited at least once).Then, of course, I read the second half, which is far better than the first. It makes me wonder if Hemingway didn't take a lesson from The Sun Also Rises and neglect to cut out the first half of a novel to make its superior posterior shine through. And yes yes, I know, his blasé, absentee writing style reflects the narrator's tone as a person distanced from life through war; I get it. It really just seems that he hit his stride somewhere in the middle where the story and writing became interesting.And the end, of course, by God. I'd give the entire novel 5 stars for the last chapter. I almost can't stand it.War's a bitch, it seems; and so are our little wars, fought daily....more

title: Audrey Hepburn
author: Paris, Barry
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I will say this: I found myself incapable of reading a lot before I had to close the book and gaze romantically at the cover, wondering how strange peI will say this: I found myself incapable of reading a lot before I had to close the book and gaze romantically at the cover, wondering how strange people would think me to be if I up and kissed it.I know I can't hold Paris too responsible for the book being so dry (thus, the three out of two); he is, after all, a biographer and not a novelist. Still, the book reads like a lecture, and a bad one at that. Every so often there is a nice little glimpse of coyness by Paris, but it is quickly overshadowed by long sections of exposition that seem only marginally necessary for us to know about Hepburn's life.I do think I learned a bit about her, which I dare say is the reason for anyone to read a bio, but I feel like many years of her life went by in a few flips of the page, which resulted in my not really getting to know her. That's silly and romantic, like anyone enraptured by Audrey's entire being, and I know she was elusive in life, a normal person outside of the lime; but, I missed the tenderness of good writing that would have made this book really good.However, the passage of her death did almost make me cry; but that might just be because she died. Still, I'm a guy so I would never publically admit that. Hmm.Ultimately, good info and good photos, but poor writing. I'm sure there's a better Hepburn book out there, I just don't think I have the energy....more

title: War and Peace
author: Tolstoy, Leo
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Good God Good Reads.It should be worth mentioning that no fair criticism of a Russian novel, whether positive or otherwise, can be delivered by someonGood God Good Reads.It should be worth mentioning that no fair criticism of a Russian novel, whether positive or otherwise, can be delivered by someone from an Occidental background. Russian literature, even adeptly translated into English, violates (minus the pejorative) the norms we Westerners value in literature, which often automatically subverts a genuine interest, appreciation, and understanding of the works, often rendering arbitrary three-star s in virtual biblio-blogispheres.Let me cite for example:-There is no central character through which we can see development, struggle, give allegiance, etc., which is so common to Western Lit.-All characters have extreme (sometimes caricature) sensibilities, often crying unconventionally or hypo-masculinely (approve or not, it is unrealistic in Western culture) and often offer despicable characteristics, leading readers to wholesale dislike everyone in the book at least once.-The narrative is not linear but rather interwoven with a variety of time periods, perspectives, and intellectual philosophizing.-The author randomly (and increasingly as the novel continues) breaks from narrative to offer pragmatic and expository explanation for penning the tome.-Et Cetera.The novel, as any 1400 page book, is taxing to read, and is provoking an eye exam next week; but despite its exhausting nature, it does one thing very well: present historic events. As Hemingway illuminates the Spanish Civil War, so too does Tolstoy illuminate the War of 1812. Tolstoy himself grants that his mission with the novel is to examine history through the scope of more microcosmic matters (i.e. viewing its effects on the individual) and to quarrel with popular representation of history by historians (man does he seem to hate them).An enormous drawback to the novel is that it seems infinite. There are many very unnecessary scenes that seem to pad the narrative for little reason and the reader is constantly tempted to put the project down.Conversely, it succeeds in its philosophical titular paradox: the book is literally about "war" and "peace" in its depiction of such times in Russia, but it is also about the adjacent wars and peaces in the lives of each man, as they go on living, those internal struggles that propagate our actions (Tolstoy does not go as far as advocate destiny, but argues against free will).In all, it's a worthy book to read, but any sprite daredevils venturing into its world must do so with ribald stubbornness and patience, as it's a doozy....more

title: The Art of Fiction: Notes on Craft for Young Writers
author: Gardner, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm using this book to teach a fiction class, so naturally I found many usable points with which to supplement my own lectures, but there are some thiI'm using this book to teach a fiction class, so naturally I found many usable points with which to supplement my own lectures, but there are some things that irk me about it.For one, Gardner and myself have very different appreciations for literature. I get it, you think Hemingway, Faulkner, and Joyce were so-so writers. I think Grendal is stupid, there. (Actually, I didn't read it; I'm just a child). It's easy to get over the more pretentious passages. At times, Gardner is so egotistical that it makes the reader laugh, which can't be a bad thing, right? Even so, there is a lot of smart discourse in the book. We start with Literary Theory, which of course, is important, then move on to the more technical aspects of writing fiction. He claims that the book is for beginning writers though some of his thoughts and analyses are grad level. Moreover, I don't know how much this book would help a new writer who wasn't taking a class to supplement it. The book gets weaker and weaker as it goes on (the first two chapters are the best) and Gardner never really gives a pragmatic approach to writing. Also, he only mentions fourish authors in some favorable way, suggesting (of course, erroneously) that he's only read these four writers.I like his style and his abruptness (however academic), and he certainly knows his stuff. Just make sure someone is supplementing your learning of writing instead of trying this thing by itself. ...more

title: War Dances
author: Alexie, Sherman
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This being the One Book One Philadelphia choice for 2011, I thought I'd support literacy in my city by reading Alexie's collection of short fiction, pThis being the One Book One Philadelphia choice for 2011, I thought I'd support literacy in my city by reading Alexie's collection of short fiction, poetry, and mix-use contemporary vignettes.I need to critique this book in two completely separate fashions:1) It is a great choice for the OBOP project, as it is easy to read and presents challenging issues of race, homophobia, and parental abandonment. These things are very important to the fabric of Philadelphia, especially to those for whom this program is organized to benefit: those who do not normally engage literature.However,2) It really was a bore to me. I liked the aformentioned topics discussed, but the writing was so elementary that I finished each episode shrugging my shoulders. Also, I was led to believe that this would really highlight Native American culture, which I was really excited about, being that I am not versed in the culture. It does, sadly, very little to illuminate modern Native American culture. I find this point most disappointing. Alexie really banks on his Native American heritage (and I do believe it had something to do with this book winning an award) but the book only barely touches on the subject. Oh and his poetry...yikes.I would recommend this book for young adult readers, not anyone interested in Native Americans or, say, good fiction....more

review: My big criticism was that in a slim novel that can be read in two sittings, there are 200 characters, most of whom make a one page appearance than disMy big criticism was that in a slim novel that can be read in two sittings, there are 200 characters, most of whom make a one page appearance than disappear. I can infer from somewhat understanding the saga literary tradition that this is an Icelandic cultural thing, so I will not include the criticism in my final assessment of the novel.I really enjoyed Gudmundsson's depiction of the mentally ill; he did so by making the psychotic delusions in the book rather poetic, perhaps suggesting that there is poetry in madness. Who can argue that? Moreover and ultimately, the book is a criticism in itself on how people with mental illnesses are handled socially in Iceland, which is parallel to how they are handled in the US. It is also a reserved submission to a life affected by a disease that man, as of now, has no ability to cure.And Hell, it wasn't about 40 Vikings and their ancestors riding around in ships....more

title: Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close
author: Foer, Jonathan Safran *
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There are two classes of readers: traditionalists, who prefer the standard literary curves, motifs, and tropes of the classics; and modernists, who stThere are two classes of readers: traditionalists, who prefer the standard literary curves, motifs, and tropes of the classics; and modernists, who strive to place themselves amongst those who push art to its limits.Foer is the latter. If he were a painter, he'd be that guy painting a square blue and saying it was representative of humanity's inner mourning over their expulsion from Eden, represented in the Mississippi Delta blues of harmonious universe. Then he'd slash the canvas with a scalpel.Although many would scratch their heads at this book (the selfsame folks who leave the Contemporary Art wing shaking their heads, no doubt), I personally found it beautiful in its innovation and unabashed uniqueness. I can see why people think of it as gimmicky; in fact, I wouldn't completely disagree. At times, I felt like saying, "I get it, pictures in the book." But all in all, using mixed media works so long as it facilitates the telling of the story. Foer simply did what every thoughtful mind of every generation did: he tried something new. Do you think Hemingway was universally appreciated when he took the then classics and started his minimalist dialogue-heavy lost gen war stories? Do you think everyone loved Kerouac's margin-to-margin stream-of-consciousness scroll rant? Do you think everyone loved e e cummings spelling his name in lower case letters while writing poems upside down with r;an(dom punc(tuate)ion st--re;wn through(out)? The answer is no; but literary history has proven that the great innovators are ultimately, greatly appreciated.Did you know Parisians originally hated the Eiffel Tower? That Philadelphians thought their regal City Hall was ugly? That San Fransiscans thought the Transamerican Pyramid to be a ruination of their skyline? Now, all three structures define their cities. In the same way, Foer defines a new literary movement.If we can get passed the photo tropes and language deconstruction, and get to the story, we have a novel that is sensitive, heart-breaking, relevant, and identifiable to all Americans who lived through 9-11. Many authors have tried to tackle the subject. Many have succeeded; others not. But what Foer does is he creates a sort of chaos that was created in this country, rolls it into a careful story, and handles it delicately....more

title: The Sun Also Rises
author: Hemingway, Ernest
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A virtual book  could never truly reveal the majesty that is Hemingway at his youngest and finest. I won't even try. All I can say is, I read thA virtual book  could never truly reveal the majesty that is Hemingway at his youngest and finest. I won't even try. All I can say is, I read this over and over, and can never get enough. Based on reality, Hemingway finds deeply routed realizations about the human condition and presents them without vast complex descriptions. Rather, it's the subtlety of this novel that makes it so fine and sincere.All of the characters hurt. They all love. Their Pamplona fiesta represents the uneasy joy of living celebrated by the eternal nucleus of the Lost Generation. The bullfights represent a communion of beauty and brutality. Impotence, bankruptcy, and inadequacy all represent patriarchal gender roles of men and the subsequent emasculation wrought from simply being born chromosome-Y style.I could go on.The fact remains that this sliver of a book holds so much in its so little. The pages are finite, but the beauty that here separates Hemingway from the rest of the Losts and furthermore from the rest of the American canon is permanent....more

review: After reading it three times over the last four years, I can honestly say that it's my favorite Kerouac. Here, the drawbacks to innocent youthful exprAfter reading it three times over the last four years, I can honestly say that it's my favorite Kerouac. Here, the drawbacks to innocent youthful expressions of non-conformity are realized. All road-trippers know that their trips end up home. But when you're Kerouac, the self-depricating King of the Beats (a title he hated), your trip doesn't end, and it leads to the Big beautiful Sur breakdown.And not a one of us, Jack, buys the ending.Kerouac and most of the beats credit Emerson for their inspiration for self-reliance. In the same-titled essay of Emerson's, he says "To be great is to be misunderstood." Fittingly, Kerouac started his journey misunderstood, and ended it famous, which, in essence, killed him.The book, in its own entirity, is wonderful, even as we watch one of our favorite authors sink irreparably, into oblivian....more

The poet herself is a well-versed (pun-obviously-intended) traveler and brings a global perspective into her scope with her collection of autonomous but partially-related poems. review: Please permit me first to say that I am not a fan of the mystery or suspense genres.Please permit me then to suggest that I was tricked into thinking Please permit me first to say that I am not a fan of the mystery or suspense genres.Please permit me then to suggest that I was tricked into thinking that's not what this was.Please finally permit me to foolishly recount how I knew this was a best-selling book and all best-selling books are mystery/suspense novels soaked up by persons with bodies soaking up the sun on beach vacations.That was mean.Anyway, I feel like Larsson was trying to be a feminist by creating Lisbeth Salander, but I'm not exactly sure that she qualifies standing next to Offred or Edna Pontellier. Rather, she reminds me of a Goth Spice Girl, with cyberpunk idiosyncrasies that weather the annoying storm of Larsson's exclusion of the titular character until well beyond the mid-point of this 600 page (by God!) novel. She's a contradictory insecure ass-kicker with bad tattoos and an incessant smoking habit. I kinda feel that Larsson was really just playing out his own sexual appetites (Larsson was a journalist, as is his main character, who, despite being 20 some-odd years older than Marilyn Manson's illegitimate love child, still manages to have sex with her an absurd number of absurd times, most likely in absurd ways).The writing is tedious, often mentions too many Apple products, and the mystery could be summed up in roughly 30 pages. title: A Moveable Feast
author: Hemingway, Ernest
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I would feel like a bastard if I gave Hemingway anything less than four stars. If I wasn't so concerned about my own feelings, I'd probably have givenI would feel like a bastard if I gave Hemingway anything less than four stars. If I wasn't so concerned about my own feelings, I'd probably have given this book two stars. If it weren't for the road trip with F. Scott Fitzgerald, one.If someone said to me they were going to give me a novel wherein Ernest Hemingway wrote an autobiographical account of Parisian ex-patriotism, the orgins of his writing craft, his relationships with Stein, Pound, and Fitzgerald, and his love for food, I would most likely sell my soul to get a copy of it. A Moveable Feast is just that, but it falls very short of the beauty that is typically Hemingway.I think it may have to do with its posthumousness. I know that Hemingway wrote The Sun Also Rises in a short amount of time then spent many moons revising it. There is a potential here that the book was finished and that Hem iced himself prior to revising the manuscript. In the end, the narrative is exciting to read, for a Hemingway fan, but it in no way has the beautiful prose normally ascribed to Hem's work.I hate to say it, but throughout the first half of the book, I found his Parisian life drab and boring. The narrative really caught stride when we found Hemingway and Fitzgerald together; we got to see Hemingway's perspective on Fitzgerald (and mind you, this novel was written long after Fitzgerald's death, so Hemingway's opinions of him overall are expressed in this young part of their relationship) and Zelda, F. Scott's wife who arguably suffered from mental disorders.I all, I wanted to eat oysters, drink everything, and read more Hemingway; I suppose AMF isn't that atypical for Hem after all....more

title: J.D. Salinger: A Life
author: Slawenski, Kenneth
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I didn't have the heart to give it one star; but had I the gumption, I would have. For a moment, I'll set aside the irony that a Salingerphile who goeI didn't have the heart to give it one star; but had I the gumption, I would have. For a moment, I'll set aside the irony that a Salingerphile who goes to great lengths to assert the author's privacy-obsession wrote a biography about him, and focus on why Random House gave a book deal to a guy who simply operates a website about Salinger. Perhaps they are finally operating under the concept of their namesake: random.Not that I think all scholars and biographers need to be professors or writers themselves, but seriously, Slawenski operates a corny looking fansite called DeadCaulfields (of all things) and doesn't have any other noteworthy criteria met to suggest he is the authority on the subject.The writing makes me feel like I am in a History class with an octogenarian professor lecturing through cotton balls. It's dry and painfully tedious. I did learn a bit about Salinger, who is certainly one of my favorite authors. What I garnered most from this book was Salinger's publication history and the plot summaries (analyses, blah) of unpublished works.What bothers me are the long winded presumptuous passages; for instance, we don't have a lot of information that describes Salinger's role in WWII, so Slawenski goes into a hefty diatribe with evidence from neighboring sources that "may" have been close to Salinger in battles to suggest what the writer himself was going through. Slawenski takes so many liberties with describing Salinger's place in the war that I forgot I was reading a bio of an author rather than a war account.Aside from that, while Slawenski does provide some insights into analyzing Salinger's literature, I can't align myself with a lot of what Slawenski suggests. There are some points of his analyses where I thought he was so off, that I stopped reading to complain about it to random local coffeeshop denizens who had the misfortune of sitting near me.Poor J.D., even one of his most obsessive fans can't respect his anonymity. But Hell, what am I saying? Bring on the posthumous collections!...more

title: Raise High the Roof Beam, Carpenters & Seymour: An Introduction
author: Salinger, J.D.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Today marks the one year anniversary of Salinger's death, and fittingly, though not purposefully, today I finished the final story of his that I had yToday marks the one year anniversary of Salinger's death, and fittingly, though not purposefully, today I finished the final story of his that I had yet to read. That is to say, that he published. After reading "Seymour" I can't help but want to write long-winded parenthetical-laced (double worded singular nouns with impregnated hyphens) sentences that go on and on and force a reader to go back to the baptismal font to capture a glistening sliver of what the Hell I'm talking about.Still, could this writing (Salinger's, not mine) be any more beautiful? For the Salinger-phile, we are always looking for insights into the enigmatic Seymour Glass, the titular protagonist but elusive character of the second novella here in question. We get it, really, we do, through his younger brother Buddy's emotional and disjointed stream of consciousness introduction to the brother who he misses. There's really a simple sweetness to the work, despite Buddy's attempt to be overly academic in his ponderings. Buddy (nee Salinger) attempts to present Seymour in perhaps an analytical objective way, but the reader is immediately immersed in the abject affection Buddy has for Seymour, wrought from incessant asides that ruminate on small anecdotal snippets from their years together. The book is touching, a display of familial love retarded by--not so glancingly--war, death, and the inability for genius to survive in its own time.Well, it's done. If I'm lucky at all, there will be some posthumous releases in my lifetime. If not, I task future geniuses to come and read what's released by my grave....more

author: Moore, Lorrie
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The trouble I have with most short story books is that I tend to forget what the first story was about by the time I get to the last one. In lieu of tThe trouble I have with most short story books is that I tend to forget what the first story was about by the time I get to the last one. In lieu of this trend wherein I do not think I inhabit my oubliette alone, most short story writers attempt to create vignettes (heavy on the French today) that are tiredly unique to each other. Moore, I think, attempts solidarity by thematically and tonally creating stories that are strikingly similar. Dare I say that each narrator has the same Mooreish wit an analyst could presume is a solid embodiment of Moore's own cynical wit and perspective?Thematically, there are golden threads that link the concepts of place or where one is from, relationships and tired fidelity, child death (heavy on the gut-Wrench today), academia's ivory toilet, and American Diaspora who live at home. America is so large, and filled with so many identities, that to be an American means to sometimes be disjointed from one's own identity. It's the willing to please but not knowing one's own pleasure ideology that pervades Americana, and Moore gets it. She gets it she gets it she gets it, by God.She's brilliant and pretty; her prose that sort of beautiful that doesn't hide its shy brilliance. It's like that blond in high school us bookish kids wished was a little smarter, to justify our lust.But really, it was just the hormones.You may not remember which story was what, but the book that is realized in their telling is one for the shelf, not a damn Kindle (tm)....more

Furthermore, the fault of my opinion of the story could very well be in the translation over Achebe's actual story-telling capacity.That being said, I chose to read this book as part of my African study while traveling to Ethiopia in DEC 2010, and although it provided me with particular insights into Africana (albeit the novel is not set in Ethiopia) I found the narrative laborious to conquer. It was one of those books where the protagonist is odious (but not in the Faulkner I love to hate Jason Compson sense), the story-line is muffled and muted, linking almost short-story-like partitions misidentified as chapters, and the central conflict arises a few short pages from the terminus.I hate to say it, but it was good thing I got sick off Ethiopian water so I could sit in my hotel room all day and finish it.All criticism aside, I did learn a lot about a story-telling tradition I was (am), admittedly, ignorant about, and that is worth two stars alone....more

title: Middlesex
author: Eugenides, Jeffrey
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The concept of "epic" in contemporary culture (beyond the childish epithet) is congruent with serial novels that conjoin fantastical elements with traThe concept of "epic" in contemporary culture (beyond the childish epithet) is congruent with serial novels that conjoin fantastical elements with traditional heroes' journeys. see Lord of the Rings, Harry Potter, et al. We diverge a bit from tradition with "Middlesex," which is a Hero(iene)'s journey where the fantasy is in public comprehension of beauty/deformity and the concept of "hero" is teamed with the more acceptable "regular person."Taking the epic approach of Greek Drama, Eugenides has us travel from Turkey to San Francisco by way of Detroit, New York, and curiously formed genitalia. You read that right. The back-story of the novel, of our protagonist's grandparents' emigration to America is cozy in the sense that it works well partnered with a warm cup of coffee in a comfy chair. It has all the romanticism and beautiful writing of a flighty love story with a touch of spice, represented by incest and war. Amazingly true to history, this part of the novel links intrinsically with Eugenides's fictionalized present tense, which is woven sheepishly throughout the beginning of the novel.The latter portion revolves around a modern intersexed individual living socially as a man, who is learning to comprehend self through an examination of progeny.There are many themes to the novel, all explored totally: gender identity, family, love, race relations (a large part of the book examines Detroit's crumbling as an American city of industry and the swept-under-the-rug ideologies of white flight and urban ghettos) and immigration, in as much as it relates to people retaining their heritage while assuming another.Very well written. It's a book of many words and pages that does not let the reader struggle while reading through, epically speaking....more

review: Though not written with any particular superb brilliance, Passing is extremely poignant when it comes to social commentary in or around Harlem in the Though not written with any particular superb brilliance, Passing is extremely poignant when it comes to social commentary in or around Harlem in the 1920s, when race turmoil was more prevalent in NYC than car horns. Clare's "passing" off as a white woman and what it means in her infidelity to her native culture is distinctly vilified by Larson, who punishes the character with death. Conversely, Irene, who is truly the protagonist, as our gaze is wholly upon her, acts out of a defense of her race, mostly, but shows the insidious side of human vengeance when posed against moral ethics.The only thing that got to me was the setting of the story. Though African American, Irene leads a very affluent lifestyle, and behaves in the Southern Gothic tradition of pampered aristocracy, which is unsettling, considering her symbol of African American righteousness in defending the value of fidelity in one's own race. In short, Irene is not the best population sample of the African American plight. Still, I think Larson was very brave and direct with this simple tale of two women, who felt the walls of racial pressure gently brushing their arms as those walls slowly moved in to crush them....more

title: The Sound and the Fury
author: Faulkner, William
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Laced throughout this book are pen marks with hints as to the timeline, characters, and characteristics of this, Faulkner's classic and beautifully moLaced throughout this book are pen marks with hints as to the timeline, characters, and characteristics of this, Faulkner's classic and beautifully morose novel. The pen marks are my own, from when I first tried to read the novel, back in college. Mysteriously, the pen marks stop around page 200, where I seem to have put the book down. Even more mysteriously, I hadn't remembered a single part of the novel when I picked it up recently for a second try.I am not sure why I don't remember The Sound and the Fury from my first read. Perhaps I wasn't ready for it; I truly believe that we mature into books, the way our taste buds mature into bitter foods. Perhaps this is why I was more open to it the second read than I was the first. Or maybe it's because I read and understood Joyce's Ulysses, which makes every other complex narrative seem coloring-book-simplistic.Whichever the case may be, I can say, with some pride, that I've ever only put down two books that I had started in my entire life. Perhaps this is just a suggestion of my fidelity, or a simple case of stubbornness. The first, Heller's Catch 22, was because nothing changed for hundreds of pages, and the gist was got. Really got. Heller, short story. Please.The other, was this. The Sound and the Fury. Upon opening the book again and seeing the collegiate scribbles of my former self, I was immediately returned to the Mississippian South, where Faulker's family (The Compsons) live their dysfunctional lives in the symbolic "the south has seemed to fall again" fashion. After putting the book down in frustration as a rosy cheeked freshman, this time I read the book in under a week. I feel manipulated. That's the only way I can describe it. Faulkner makes his readers feel what he wants them to feel and leads them where he wants them to go. Just as soon as I think I've misunderstood something (the androgynous double naming of Quentin: is it a guy or a girl? Oh. Both.) Faulkner lets me realize that he intended to distract me before letting me know I was in fact, on track. It’s a weird world, to be in Faulkner’s, where first person narratives of persons with mental retardation and the poetic stream of consciousness of depressed quasi-incestial Harvardites aim to distress the reader just as much as they aim to impress them. I always thought that I was missing something, only to find out that he purposely withheld that something until he was ready, while always leaving subtle hints all the way.I felt like the idiot who watches The Sixth Sense a second time and can’t believe he didn’t see it coming.In the end, the reader gets four sections, each distinct, and each incredible in its own way. We are confused by Benji, our first narrator, whose mental retardation plays with time like the old Quantum Leap show (yep). We fall in love with Quentin, whose narrative (June second 1910) is one of the most beautiful pieces of writing I’ve ever read, subtle and tragic and gentle. We hate the odious Jason, a bigot with a cold heart and migraines. And we recognize the class divide and implications of such with Dilsey, the family’s servant. I can’t say this book is for everyone, but it’s certainly for me. Once again my own pen has been threatened in the vanity that is aspiring to not sit in the shadow of this monolith. ...more

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray
author: Wilde, Oscar
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: **spoiler alert** This novel was published serially (seriously), and it almost reads like it. I am not sure of the history concerning the construction**spoiler alert** This novel was published serially (seriously), and it almost reads like it. I am not sure of the history concerning the construction of the book, but it almost seems as if Wilde was gauging the public's opinion of his work while constructing the succeeding chapters. I cite, as example of this, how his characters, particularly the titular protagonist, develop such outstanding (not used as a complementary adjective) changes of personhood as to be rendered unbelievable. Gray goes from being a charming and handsome youth to a murderous and odious madman, whose decisions, one after another, make the reader dislike him more and more. Regardless of Wilde's unbelievable character changes, the novel does find a refined word-craftman's-ship, namely in the quips and often misogynistic epithets ("What are women?"; "Sphinxes without riddles.") of Lord Henry, who I daresay has the cheeky sort of tongue play that Wilde himself had. Oh Oscar, could you not resist spitting your own words into your character's mouth? I jest, what author could?At length, in this rather obvious morality tale, there are a number of social criticisms to be offered, including, but not extensively: social class and the ridicule of the higher ranks of society who believe other classes to be subhuman; male/female relationships, which Wilde categorizes as fickle and capricious (I wonder why); and the mistake of envying youth, which, at one point or another, we all make.The latter, the central conflict of the story, is the most poignant. Wilde suggests that we are ignorant to be nostalgic about youth. After all, we often look upon our younger selves with disdain, wondering how we could fall for our past follies, while ignoring our present missteps. I think, rather, the message is that what we miss isn't our youth, but our lost energy, the way youth seem to have so much less responsibility than the old, but seem to squander it in ignorance. Of course, we fail to see that while we are musing over our gone youth, our older selves gaze back from the future and beg us to muse no longer, but to live.But what the Hell do I know? I'm only 28 for God's sakes....more

review: What attracts me to Vonnegut is the austere plainness in sincerity he crafts to instigate his higher morals. They may be redundant, his morals, but thWhat attracts me to Vonnegut is the austere plainness in sincerity he crafts to instigate his higher morals. They may be redundant, his morals, but they are perhaps so redundant that they act as applicable sources--strength in numbers, if you will--to validate and justify his purposes.Mother Night is a plot driven, almost detective-y novel with twists and turns, espionage, love triangles, and the common Vonnegutese humor that keeps his readers coming back but often has them confused as to which novel they just read. I think all of this is besides the original point. It's to the moral, what he engages the reader with at the start of the introduction in the most recent edition, that passes the plot and surfaces to the reader's appreciation of the text.In short, I do not know if I will remember Howard Campbell Jr. and his sometimes American spy, Nazi propagandanist, New York recluse, playwright, sisterphile self. What I will remember, is that Vonnegut is showing us again how stupid war is. How the evil in people is registered in their inability to recognize their own hatred and righteousness is no worse than the next man's same.That blowing things up, simply, will never do....more

review: In terms of war criticism via literature, I do not suppose a more well-crafted novel could have been written. No matter how often I read this book, I In terms of war criticism via literature, I do not suppose a more well-crafted novel could have been written. No matter how often I read this book, I still get the shivers, the smiles, and the hopeless faith in people, despite how much we seem to like blowing each other up.I went to Dresden this summer, that's why I reread the book. And Vonnegut's sort of emotion enriched apathy, pathetic lamentations and snide witicism does as much justice to the city as can be done.Is it sci-fi? Can be considered as such. Though I think those considering it such are missing the point.What I like most about this book, is that, unlike any other Vonnegut fiction, we see him here at his most honest, exposed, and vulnerable. To be a present witness of one of America's most greatest war crime atrocities, to survive it, must deflate one's desire to represent mankind totally; rather, for Vonnegut, we are shown how a man can still consider himself a member of mankind, despite how wildly he shakes his head at its misdeeds....more

Having since beeThis was the only book of my astounding Contemporary Literature class in college that didn't grab my attention upon first reading it. Having since been to Venice, and recalling that the novel's main setting was in the city of changing mazes, I decided to give it a second chance.Thank God for maturity.Although a small book that is encountered and dispatched quickly, Winterson includes many themes that are valuable in one's general appreciation of literature. As you may expect, the concept of Passion, the anthropomorphism of it as a protagonist, and the characters' need/reaction to it are central to the construction of the novel.I appreciated the accurate descriptions of Venice, a bizarre, beautiful, and at times nauseating city. I also liked the inclusion of the very Latin-literary trope of magic realism, which must be viewed with a suspension of disbelief.Ultimately, it's a book for people in the Venetian know; I don't think those who've not been to Venice can appreciate the novel nearly, as my collegiate past self can attest....more

review: Lives vivasect.And what happens is, there's always something up in the sky, taking our attention, which prevents us from acknowledging the shoulders wLives vivasect.And what happens is, there's always something up in the sky, taking our attention, which prevents us from acknowledging the shoulders we're rubbing just walking along.McCann uses a tightrope walker, the distorted dregs of used coffee grinds in NYC, a web of people knotted, and his own need to digest 9-11 to organize this novel.Oh, and Hookers.Monks.Hackers.Soldiers.Soldier hackers.Spraypaint artists.Judges.Their wives.Et. al.I'm always at an impasse when it comes to literature concerning what I prefer, the plot or the wordplay. In the case of Let the Great World Spin, I'm given the synthesis of the two. McCann's words are pretty little flutters against an otherwise rancid backdrop of the Bronx in the summer heat. Moreover, though the story maintains one lip-biting element after another, you get the sense of sincere calm and beauty seen in the world, page after page. He never directly touches on it, but there is a lot of 9-11 wrapped up in this story. You can't have someone tightrope walk the twin towers without giving your audience images of them falling. You can't mention war without thinking of all the young lives lost. McCann doesn't seem to be making personal statements about these things, but rather, seems to simply show they exist, and tries to find a lens by which to make them not hurt so badly.Great read....more

title: Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?
author: Dick, Philip K.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have to give credit to Dick for insight and set precedent for myself for the lack-of-fondness I maintain for the science fiction genre. Rest assuredI have to give credit to Dick for insight and set precedent for myself for the lack-of-fondness I maintain for the science fiction genre. Rest assured, my low scoring is a reflection of the latter.What I really like about the book is that there is a specific moral quandary with the story. Are androids alive? Is it wrong to kill them and see them as inhuman?Dick poses these questions really well by comparing android prejudice to that of the colonial American slavery of Africans. Moreover, Dick's protagonist wrestles with the conundrum of killing beings he develops feelings for. The major disparity between humans and robots is the former's ability to feel empathy, measured in a ersatz religion dubbed Mercerism. Robots are not empathetic creatures, and it is thereby assumed that they do not maintain valuable life. This is brilliantly contrasted by Dick's show of human characters who are not very empathetic at all: "specials" or "chickenheads" who have low IQs and aren't seen as members of society; a protagonist who cheats on his wife with a Robo-babe (whose small breasts are referenced far too much; I get it Dick, you like em tiny), and values animals so much that he pretends to own one.Why I don't particularly like the book lies in the story-telling. Like many Sci-fi writers, the focus is on the ingenuity of the inventions and philosophies innate in the potential future, rather than basic plot movement and beautiful wordplay. For instance, in one scene, two characters face each other in mortal combat. One character flees into a back room. The other shoots him (?) and he dies. I'm no creative writing teacher (ha) but you can't shoot someone in another room. Dick violates a lot of the spatial constructs of narrative, and this is emphasized in the very quick, very unexciting, and very anti-climactic actions scenes. And the end is one long acid trip of what-is-going-on?-I-wish-he'd-add-more-relevant-analogies-to-slavery.Alas, it's only science fiction.Weird Science.Fiction.Okay....more

title: Still Life with Woodpecker
author: Robbins, Tom
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have to give props to Tom Robbins for being a modernist and not allowing the strict confines of traditional literature to retard his self-expressionI have to give props to Tom Robbins for being a modernist and not allowing the strict confines of traditional literature to retard his self-expression, but I do have to be hasty in saying that even Jackson Pollock paintings are sometimes head-scratchers. Tom Robbins has ADD.What's fun about the story is that it's outlandish, ridiculous, and unapologetically goofy, in the cartoon sense. Robbins has fun seemingly doing whatever he wants with his story, which causes equal amounts of scrunched foreheads and belly-laughs from his readers. He is meta-fictitious, philosophical, and deep.What bothers me about the story is that...well, he stops telling it. The first third of the book, the narrative is flowing very well; the later two-thirds are soap-box wax-intellectualizing. Now, don't get me wrong, I want authors to make me think, but his patchwork additions of philosophy do not connect to each other or the overlaying story. It's as if he simply felt like sharing a thought in the middle of the narrative. In lieu of this, the book was hard to read. I found myself distracted frequently (however, he even mentions meta-fictitiously that he's doing this to his readers...so he knows, and I suppose I have to award him points for this insight). In all, I can't fault the book that much. It's such a breath of fresh air to see new literary work that attempts to redefine art, even if it is just paint splatters....more

If I'm being honest, however, I probably gave it such a high ranking because I know it's very famous.Here's the deal: it's a sad and sickening depiction of real life human evil and one boy's fight for survival. Simple.The read is not challenging, nor does it take very long. In this edition, the most interesting part was in the author's new edition preface, where he discusses his reasons for writing the narrative, the most striking being that he wanted to make an account of the atrocity for the posterity of history (What is, Rhyme Time Alex?). author: Atwood, Margaret*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Let me preface this criticism with the fact that I traveled to DC to meet Atwood and have her sign my copy of this book, evidence that I am, at heart,Let me preface this criticism with the fact that I traveled to DC to meet Atwood and have her sign my copy of this book, evidence that I am, at heart, in the literary sense, a fan.As for this novel, there isn't a lot of redeeming quality. Unlike Oryx and Crake, which is ambiguous and interesting with its portrayal of pre-apocalyptic genetic genocide, The Year of the Flood is too blatant and gimmicky. Despite the fact that most general readers (who I like to call, beach readers) like their stories wrapped up in a kind and comforting bow, Atwood traditionally institutes ambiguity, which forces her readers to interpret literature for themselves. This is lost in a lot of modern/contemporary literature. Unfortunately, there is not ambiguity in this novel. And, dare I say, she almost ruins the ambiguity of Oryx and Crake.She attempts to tell the same story as the "prequel" novel through the perspective of the cultish vegan group the God's Gardeners as they prepare for Crake's Armageddon. While reading, however, I never cared for the characters nearly as much as I did say Jimmy, or the Snowman. The book is long and long winded and is bisected by BAD lyrical poems that really could have been skipped. When the characters of the first book are reintroduced, the reader gets a wholly new perspective on them, and not a perspective we want. Rather, the information provided is too much and hurts the mystique that the previous novel developed. Moreover, you get the sense that the “clever” relating of the two books is wholly forced.Her criticisms in the book are great: FEMA's reaction to NOLA makes a snide appearance, genetics, veganism, cultish religions, gender roles, etc. In all, however, the story is one you really just can't wait to finish, and not because you want to find out how it turns out.The worst part, is that there will probably be a third. But if history serves us, she's usually hit or miss; so perhaps after a miss, she'll hit.I suppose my signed copy will sit on my shelf for awhile....more

review: In this genetic dystopian tale, Atwood focuses on the positioning of humanity within the realms of animal/vegetable, art/science, and friendship/love In this genetic dystopian tale, Atwood focuses on the positioning of humanity within the realms of animal/vegetable, art/science, and friendship/love from an interestingly distracted and peripheral standpoint.Jimmy, or Snowman, lives in a world sans humana, and goes on to recant the story of humana's unfortunate sans-ing. title: The Catcher in the Rye
author: Salinger, J.D.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In rereading this book (for the third time) for a class, I rediscovered one of the best books of self-discovery. What Salinger can really do, is give In rereading this book (for the third time) for a class, I rediscovered one of the best books of self-discovery. What Salinger can really do, is give us vivid descriptions of sadness in such beatiful ways, that his readers forget what they're reading is struggle, pain, and the half-emptied glass realization that perhaps this is all we get.I do not have to elaborate on the themes of the book as they are as recounted as parables from the Bible; but I will say that there are a few books out there that are just about the way all books should be written. And I don't mean the style, the syntax, the tropes, the character development, plot, metaphor, description, blah et cetera blah; I mean everyone calling him/herself a writer should begin with a passion to be as honest as this man....more

title: To Kill a Mockingbird
author: Lee, Harper
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If it is true that To Kill a Mockingbird is considered more important than the Bible to read before one dies (I read that somewhere), I can certainly If it is true that To Kill a Mockingbird is considered more important than the Bible to read before one dies (I read that somewhere), I can certainly imagine why. As far as parables of morality are concerned, my present mind cannot think of a book that more openly challenges and vivifies the spirit of man with it's hard prosecution of our greatest flaws and a tenderness for our kindest sensibilities.The story itself makes one feel the youthful yearing of childhood, in the way we could leave for the woods to play in the morning and scratch our heads in curiosity come night, as it came unexpectedly. Where Lee really succeeds is her characters. Atticus the noble lawyer, a widower concerned with the morality of his children. Jem, his son, learning the ways of the world by pushing against them and questioning why they are ways. And Scout, our narrator, typifies the innocence of not comprehending gender roles but in trusting others, ending up being one of the most tender characters in literary history.Even Boo Radley, a name that makes children shudder, makes us shudder for other reasons.In all, it is a morality tale, written with pensive simplicity and honesty. I'm with those who think it's one of those books people need to read before they die, Bible be damned."Atticus, he was real nice...""Most people are, Scout, when you finally see them."...more

title: Nine Stories
author: Salinger, J.D.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I bought this collection of short stories for my cousin about 8 years ago. She was then 13. I had read Catcher in the Rye and thought that a young girI bought this collection of short stories for my cousin about 8 years ago. She was then 13. I had read Catcher in the Rye and thought that a young girl might get something vivid and prolific from a novel about being a vivid and prolific social reject.Eight years later, Salinger died and I read the book. The nine stories contained in this aptly titled book were collected from various publications that Salinger patronized over his short and cryptic public writing career. Almost all deal with the concept of post-War trauma, and some feature the beloved Glass family, which is Salinger's surrogate literary Brady Bunch.I have to say, of the nine, seven made me pause and wish Salinger was more extraverted in his literary genius. The not so good ones, namely, the second and third, were still tremendous. The others, short and never sweet, range from a lying 19 year old Parisian-American emigrant to Canada who disguises himself as an art professor at an unlicensed art school, to a story of a genius ten-year-old who believes himself to be the reincarnation of a near Bodhisattva and who can predict the deaths of people, including his own.However, nothing can live up to "A Perfect Day for Bananafish," which, must be the best short story I've ever read. Casual in its cruelty. Beautiful in its playful construction. Stalling in its conclusion. It left me short of breath. Salinger was a master of being a master. He wrote dialogue brilliantly, and his characters are memorable because they are so unlike us that they are essentially our mirror reflections. In a drastic way, he's just so right about everything.Please God someone jimmy open his posthumous writings file....more

title: Everville        (Book of the Art #2)
author: Barker, Clive*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Barker's biggest fear with this book was a "Two Towers" complex; or, perhaps an "Empire Strikes Back" complex, suggesting that he was afraid the middlBarker's biggest fear with this book was a "Two Towers" complex; or, perhaps an "Empire Strikes Back" complex, suggesting that he was afraid the middle book of his trilogy would be like most middle books: a bridge, and nothing else. In his apprehension, he does create a book that works standalone, a novel that dives much deeper into the mythology of the first book, but he does so in an almost madman sort of way. Quite often I feel like Barker doesn't have command over his world. That the creatures and aspects of his alternate reality have seized his pen and are ice skating with epilepsy while he sits there confused and forlorn. Like the Great and Secret Show, Barker is fantastic with his beginning and end, but in the middle, a few hundred pages could be cut out. He overcomplicates the story with characters that don't really need to be there, whose relationship to the story is suspect at best, and his apocolyptic ending sort of just fizzled out like a flat Coke, sort of disappointing. Still, despite me aprobation, I read the entire thing in a few days, which says something. Barker is a master of narrative, bringing his reader along for the ride. I'm no prude, but I can go without the grotesque sex of the story and for God's sake, dialogue needs to be unique. Why does every character sound the same? While Barker fails often, he also succeeds, at least in writing a story that's fun to read. Just don't ever ask him what the story's about, I doubt he'll know. And don't ask him when the third book of the trilogy is coming out, his answer will be the same.In the end, I like "Empire Strikes Back" the best....more

title: The Great and Secret Show        (Book of the Art #1)
author: Barker, Clive*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In an exercise to get in touch with my deceased teenage self, I decided to read one of the books that really got me into reading and, incidentally, wrIn an exercise to get in touch with my deceased teenage self, I decided to read one of the books that really got me into reading and, incidentally, writing. Having noted already that as the palate of age matures, the enjoyment of things past lessens, I wanted the familiar nostalgia of a book from my shelf that had my old, perhaps slightly smaller, fingerprints.The first of an incomplete trilogy, The Great and Secret Show is a novel of fantasy, horror, and sex. I must say that part of me was pleasantly surprised when rereading this book, to the extent that Barker does have a great command of language, imagination, and descriptive prowess. Following in the vein of much of his work, Barker creates new worlds, new creatures, and a mythology that is as confusing as it is intriguing. Unlike a lot of modern day mystery genres (LOST immediately comes to mind) where writers and producers have a certain grasp of the overall story, it seems here that Barker allows his imagination to run in a sort of stream of consciousness way, not really knowing where the stream's flowing. I know I know, Barker fans don't jump down my throat; I know he meticulously outlines his novels and has infinite folders of notes for such, but this book really doesn't seem to know the answers to it's own questions. I don't find this to be a particularly deal-breaking problem, but I hastily suggest to anyone who doesn't want to be frustrated with covert plots, be warned.What works is the interesting plot, the beginning, and the end.What doesn't work is about 400 pages in the middle. Barker is a great example of what modern day editors invest in red pens for. There are so many unnecessary characters and scenes in the book that would work well to be omitted. Moreover, the characters all seem redundant, each speaking with the same dialogue inflections and are generally indistinct.Still, I'm nothing if not nostalgic, so Barker's world, adopted the second time, was just as thrilling as the first....more

title: Travels with Charley: In Search of America
author: Steinbeck, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Perhaps John Steinbeck will always be remembered most for his fiction and how his portrayal of the working class in America changed the viscera of labPerhaps John Steinbeck will always be remembered most for his fiction and how his portrayal of the working class in America changed the viscera of labor laws and fairness in our country. What may get swept under the rug, are narratives like this that show Steinbeck's personal side, a hybrid of boyish nomadic desire and mature observation and need to understand.The book is Steinbeck and his dog Charley driving around the country for three months "in search of America"; every person I've talked to who has read the book (college professors and that guy I met at the park today) has agreed it makes them desire nothing more than to get a dog and take off. There is a beautiful balance in what Steinbeck does, and the romanticism he creates about the open road and what it means to be American swim evenly through his loneliness and exhilaration at the world unfolding around him.A very sweet aspect of the book is his relationship with Charley, a pompous French poodle that is his travel mate. Steinbeck makes no attempt to show his utmost love for the dog and the adventures are often highlighted by Charley's reactions to the surrounding, even trumping Steinbeck's own experiences.Steinbeck is not considered a humorist, but he should be. I found myself laughing out loud from his sexually enticing a moose in Maine to his trying to convince Charley to piss on an ancient redwood in California. There are aspects of sadness in his journey, but they are massaged tender with the comedy that accompanies it always.Does Steinbeck ever "find" America? My answer is, can anyone? This travel journal comes at a very tumultuous time in American history. The Red Scare was in full affect and desegregation was causing serious tension in the south. Steinbeck analyzes this, and is as brutally truthful as he is distant about it.A quick, beautiful and necessary read for anyone with a wanderlust and the brilliance to recognize the unparalleled companionship of a dog....more

title: A Christmas Carol
author: Dickens, Charles
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's funny the books that slip by you. I feel like there's an everpresent list of books one "should have read." When I once told one of my favorite EnIt's funny the books that slip by you. I feel like there's an everpresent list of books one "should have read." When I once told one of my favorite English professors that no matter how many classics I read, I still don't feel well read, he responded that at seventy-something years old, he still doesn't feel read. Better get used to it.But I like to play catch-up nonetheless. As classic as Christmas stories get, A Christmas Carol is certainly the flagship. After having seen many cinematic, theatrical, and Philadelphian Macy's Department Store Dickens's Village representations of Dickens's story, I finally read the book, which not surprisingly, was very much like its representations. The easy-to-read morality tale is as simply orchestrated as the message is simple to grasp. Essentially, we have life, we can choose to enjoy it or choose to not. Period. Dickens states his claim at which path is more enlightened, and after reading Scrooge's story, one can't help but agreeing. Interestingly, this very common and culturally significant story still touches the reader in an intrinsic and fundemental way. I got a little teary when Belle broke off her engagement to Scrooge, even though I knew it was coming. Bah humbug to being a sap.The one thing the book provides that cannot be represented elsewhere is the meta-fiction that Dickens inlcudes, occasionally pulling back from the story and directly talking to the audience, which is a pleasure and fun to take in.It's a classic, so catch-up....more

title: The Awakening
author: Chopin, Kate
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Perhaps the most revolutionary novel in Feminist Literature, Chopin chances ridicule and social ostracism by suggesting women have a right to their owPerhaps the most revolutionary novel in Feminist Literature, Chopin chances ridicule and social ostracism by suggesting women have a right to their own lives.This novel, published in 1899, is the precedent to the entire feminist movement, featuring a female protagonist who suddenly "awakens" and realizes that she should not let anyone, not a husband, children, or society, dictate what she is mandated to do with herself. What makes this novel so remarkable, besides its wit and beauty, and its social commentary, is that Chopin stood up for something far before it was the status quo to do so. This novel, after many publishers refused to endorse it, ended up stirring serious criticism from intellectuals and the literati at the turn of the century. Her villainess status lasted until her death, and so she never knew that her novel would be the spur that led women to social independence.My only complaint as a contemporary feminist is that the action that awakens our protagonist is her falling in love with a man other than her husband; I would argue that to align with modern feminism, a woman would not need a man at all to "wake up" to her own concept of independence. Although, I swiftly mention that choosing who one loves is a statement of independence in itself. As Chopin herself puts it, in the short story "The Story of an Hour": ". . .that blind persistence with which men and women believe they have a right to impose a private will upon a fellow-creature."This book is a quick and easy read that anyone interested in feminism should read and everyone not interested in feminism should be forced to.Today it's easy to believe in equal rights; Chopin struggled to make this lasting note hum....more

title: Zeitoun
author: Eggers, Dave
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have a very strange and very personal relationship with New Orleans, and seeing a book recently published about Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath I have a very strange and very personal relationship with New Orleans, and seeing a book recently published about Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath on the Crescent City was something that caught my attention. Five years after the storm, NOLA is still very much devastated; whole neighborhoods, like the Lower 9th Ward, are empty fields with stone steps sitting alone where they used to lead up to houses. The fear of many New Orleaneans and myself, is that the nation has in all, forgotten about the plight in the Gulf Coast or has assumed it's been fixed.It hasn't.I was enthralled to see a new novel chronicling the plight of a NOLA family because I thought it would really bring attention back to a place that so seriously needs attention.The book follows the Zeitoun family, a Muslim family, as they struggle with post-Katrina New Orleans. The novel mainly focuses on anti-Islamic sentiment and the egregious denial of personal liberty inflicted upon persons by the US government, but does not really touch on New Orleans. I think it's important to read this book for the human rights violations perpetrated by the government, and I'm eager to learn how this might cause waves, but I wanted more NOLA. I wanted more New Orleans culture and depiction of its citizens. Dave Eggers is a great journalist, interviewer, and humanitarian, but he is not a good writer. The prose is very dry and very mundane....more

title: A Gate at the Stairs
author: Moore, Lorrie
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Lorrie Moore has a way with words. When I met her at a book signing for A Gate at the Stairs in Philadelphia, I commented as she was signing my book tLorrie Moore has a way with words. When I met her at a book signing for A Gate at the Stairs in Philadelphia, I commented as she was signing my book that it must get a little boring writing the same thing over and over again. She said, you're just lucky I haven't signed it Morrie Loore, which I've done a few times.I myself and a lot of the authors that I favor tend to value wordplay and the artistic bastardization and commandeering of language to fit our needs, rather than focus on plot-driven narrative. Hemingway was such a writer. Moore is such a writer. Not granting that Moore herself would vouchsafe this philosophy, her novel could be used as evidence for the prosecution.The book tells a very dramatic story of an almost flatly affected young college girl dealing with being a flatly affected college girl from a midwestern town who nannies for a white couple that has adopted a biracial ("mixed") baby. Although at times the plot takes very melodramatic turns that spiral into tense horizons, Moore's focus on tangential narratives and brilliant similes work wonders for the reader. She is a natural at wordplay. A sated satirist, I think she would say herself. Dry, humorous, witty, and bucolic. She does a tremendous job mixing sadness and comedy, which has been a benchmark for her literature for years. The titular metaphor of the Gate at the Stairs shows up endlessly through the narrative, often showing the separation of things: races, adults from children, lovers from lovers, life from non-life (not death), etc. Ultimately, Moore crafts a very poetic and pretty novel about some very not-pretty things, and guides the reader through complication to get to a point of crystal clarity....more

title: Fugitives and Refugees: A Walk in Portland, Oregon
author: Palahniuk, Chuck*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Palahniuk is a Portland native interested in the most socially deviant aspects of the Rose City, which he artfully assebles in the collage Fugitives aPalahniuk is a Portland native interested in the most socially deviant aspects of the Rose City, which he artfully assebles in the collage Fugitives and Refugees. Interdisplaced throughout the narrative are sightseeing tours for the unusual traveler and "postcards" from Chuck's own life out in Oregon.The book is short and sweet, easy to read, and perhaps low on the must reads of Chuck's bibliography, but if you're planning a trip to Portland, seriously, why not?I've been to Portland twice and was amazed with a city that was very interested in its relationship to the natural world, despite being a "big" city. (It's really quite small). The book acts as a sort of guide for non-touristy Portland things that you most likely wouldn't want to experience if you were to travel there.Still, it's fun.The most important thing to know about a place you're traveling to is how the locals view it. Philadelphians don't eat cheesesteaks and Chicagoans don't go near the Sears (Willis) Tower. Learn the locals, and you learn a place. One of the ways to learn Portland is through Chuck....more

title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone        (Harry Potter, #1)
author: Rowling, J.K.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am ing The Sorcerer's Stone for the entire Harry Potter series, instead of each individual book.I have to admit forthright, and modestly so, tI am ing The Sorcerer's Stone for the entire Harry Potter series, instead of each individual book.I have to admit forthright, and modestly so, that I was for so very long, a Harry Potter hater. (Wisest is the mind that can be changed).It is my stance, even after reading these genius books, that I do not like magic, fantasy, or children's literature. I do not care for books written for children, nor do I like simplistic infantile reading. Perhaps I'm too closly removed from the groggy-morning college classrooms that taught me to pretentiously value complex works of suffering and coy comedy, or perhaps I'm at the age where I need to seriously attempt the seriousness of adulthood so much so that I pillow-suffocate the small boy on his primary color dinosaur bedspread that I once was. Regardless of the reason, while half the world was reveling in Harry Potter mania, I turned an elevated nose.But I was wrong.At least I can admit that, right?The Harry Potter series is perhaps one of the most significant additions to literature since its cohort in the fantasy epic, Lord of the Rings. What Rowling has done with this series is create a world that is so vivid and approachable, with characters that are so simple to connect with, in an active plot that is so narcotically gripping, that readers desire it like a car-crash morphine IV drip. The writing is intense, precise, and intoxicating so much so that finishing the story is like sending a child off to college, where you know they are still yours but they will never be the same (groggily learning the pillow suffocating techniques of suffering and coy comedic literature). At first using a basic mystery novel approach to cyclic story-telling, wherein all problems are resolved by the end and turns dictate the surprise and shocking endings, the series quickly becomes very dark, often utilizing death and evil to force the protagonists into tribulations worthy of the adult world. Never scant on philosophizing, Rowling uses characters to initiate discourse on key contests in life: the concept of death, friendship, fear, and love. Although geared toward a youthful audience, the Potter series becomes very relavant to older readers as the characters encounter problems not foreign to our muggle adults.This series is intelligent, well-written, and I believe a functioning part of the literary canon. I've become a believer.But I still won't read Twilight....more

title: Who Is Mark Twain?
author: Twain, Mark
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Mark Twain is perhaps the most quoted American author in history. His one-line adages serve as witticisms for almost any occasion (I've heard him readMark Twain is perhaps the most quoted American author in history. His one-line adages serve as witticisms for almost any occasion (I've heard him read at weddings and funerals). What we have in this release is a collection of some previously published but mostly unpublished short essays and stories by Twain taken from the almost half million pages of literature that he left behind at his death. Some essays mirror the hilarity of Twain's traditional style, while others are curt and serious, seeming to end when the author was done with the thought (often before finishing it). The short stories of the collection are classic Twain, and provide an entertaining front while manintaining an insightful underbelly. "The Music Box" will just make you laugh. A lot. Twain is a writer that I could read ceaselessly. He reminds me of the joy that comes out of art, when we're so used to finding the brilliance of how it relates to our misery....more
