author: Kerouac, Jack
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The road continues on, as it seems to always, in Jack Kerouac's follow-up to his most famous novel On the Road, with this book of Buddhism, hiking, anThe road continues on, as it seems to always, in Jack Kerouac's follow-up to his most famous novel On the Road, with this book of Buddhism, hiking, and the prototypical drunk orgy everywhichway of the Beats. What differs about this book in comparison to the others of the Duluoz Legend is its approach to Eastern Philosphy, specifically Buddhism. Keraouc uses Buddhist thought to convey both his enjoyment and lamentation of the world, polar properties of his emphatic appreciation for life and his ceaseless love of "the red port," which accelerated his tailspin and early death. There is also a lot of talk of hiking in the book and Kerouac gives a fair description of taking to the wilderness, not simply giving the animalistic transcendental joy of connecting with nature, but also providing the realistic pain endured (or sometimes not) in partaking in such a physical challenge. "Trails are like that: you're floating along in a Shakespearean Arden paradise and expect to see nymphs and fluteboys, then suddenly you're struggling in a hot broiling sun of hell in dust and nettles and poison oak. . .just like life."But what I or anyone reads Kerouac for is not the plot of the story but the insight he gives by which we can create ours. His deep thoughtfulness, subtracting the wine, lays an interesting blueprint outlining a fine way to enjoy this life we're all stuck living. "But let the mind beware, that though the flesh be bugged, the circumstances of existence are pretty glorious."Overall, I'd say that anyone who has enjoyed anything else that Kerouac has written will likewise enjoy this. If there's one thing that Jack is, it's consistent....more

title: Walden
author: Thoreau, Henry David
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have to admit I'm a little shocked by how much my and Thoreau's philosophies do not align. I'm a big fan of Emersonian and Whitman(ian?) transcendenI have to admit I'm a little shocked by how much my and Thoreau's philosophies do not align. I'm a big fan of Emersonian and Whitman(ian?) transcendentalism, and I figured Thoreau would be of the same ilk, having attempted to put Emerson's Self-Reliance rhetoric into practice. And although Walden is written very well, in fact it is witty and snide with pointed clever quips, it pretty much is a pretentious account of a two year sojourn by a man who is narrow in his scope of how life should be lived. Don't get me wrong, I've found some incredible quotes from the book:"Books must be read as deliberately and reservedly as they are written.""You can't kill time without hurting eternity.""Heaven is under out feet as well as over our heads."but the majority of the book is Thoreau's admonishing of lifestyles that are not his own. For example, Thoreau was a vegetarian who admited to eating meat and fish but claimed that anyone who would do so is poisoning themselves and not wise. Moreover, he claimed things like senses dull our human experience, claiming that all food should be bland and that those who drink coffee and wine are foolish. I understand people making personal life choices, but that does not mean someone else's choices make them foolish or weak. Thoreau is harsh in his treatment of others, concluding in a very inflamatory comment, claiming "how you and I, can live thsi slimy beastly life, eating and drinking." Wow.Moreover, Thoreau goes into vivid detail about the nobility of his outdoor lifestyle, loves it so much, yet lives there a total of 2 whole years. Then he goes back to the city and society. Seems a bit hypocritical to me.The majority of the book is filled with strange meanderings and descriptions of mundane things, which is why most of it is cut out in literature texts. Still, it's worth the read. The chapters Economy and Conclusion are where all the decent meat is....more

review: I have to give Atwood a little leeway on this novel because it was her first, but it was a bit difficult to get through. Atwood does a great job imagiI have to give Atwood a little leeway on this novel because it was her first, but it was a bit difficult to get through. Atwood does a great job imagining place; her description and idealization of Toronto is very appealing to her reader, but she has yet to master character. The dynamic and perhaps overly analyzed modern characters (Offred, Grace Marks)in her later novels provide the thrust that her stories depend on. Unfortunately, this early in her writing career, she had not mastered such effects, and her characters are flat and downright dispicable. The male lead in the book was perhaps the most awful and annoying character I'd ever encountered. I don't want to take too much from Atwood with this novel; after all, it was a precurser to the amazing literature she's produced since. I suppose every marathon runner started by tying their shoes....more

title: The Devil in the White City: Murder, Magic, and Madness at the Fair That Changed America
author: Larson, Erik*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is one of the best books I've read in awhile. Eric Larson creatively and intelligently recreates events leading up to, during, and after the ColuThis is one of the best books I've read in awhile. Eric Larson creatively and intelligently recreates events leading up to, during, and after the Columbian Exhibition, or, the Chicago World's Fair, which became responsible for the concept of the modern cities that we live in today. Larson interweaves with this the story of Dr. H. H. Holmes, a psychopathic murderer who cased the fairgrounds for young women (incidently, he was held and hanged in Moyemensing prison, which was five blocks from my apartment in Philadelphia and where there is now an ACME, where I shop for food!!).The Chicago World's Fair was considered to be the greatest event in American history other than the Civil War, in terms of its effect on the country itself. It spawned new ideas of architecture, the City Beautiful Project (the idea that making cities beautiful with parks and art would raise morale and quality of life), and Pabst Blue Ribbon (which won its blue ribbon there).Other notables include the Ferris Wheel and Cracker Jacks.This is truly an incredible book for anyone who loves American History, Mass Murder stories, Architecture, and/or Chicago. Larson writes the book in a way that isn't the mundane textbook non-fiction. It reads like a novel penned by an artisan hand....more

title: The Afterlife and Other Stories
author: Updike, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When John Updike recently passed away, he wrote a poem suggesting that the world would forget him.After his life, I read the Afterlife and found that When John Updike recently passed away, he wrote a poem suggesting that the world would forget him.After his life, I read the Afterlife and found that despite death, the human echo can be as meaningful as the words spoke when the voice was alive. (barf).Regardless, Updike crafts a short story collection that hits home in almost every piece. Almost all dealing with adultery, some with mommy/son issues, and some with death (none about the actual afterlife), Updike's stories often make one pause, look up from their book, and think.What really gets you about this book is Updike's prose style. He writes his stories very simplistically, in the sense that there is no high drama or striking twists and turns. Rather, his narratives are brief glimpses in people's lives that jump quickly through years and facts as if they were matters-of-facts. His word play and discriptions of hard-to-discribe things are impecable.For instance, the dentist: that feeling of a loose and wiggling tooth; Updike discribes it as a painful tickle. Arrowhead accurate if you ask me. This book of stories was a delight to read from start to finish....more

title: The Road
author: McCarthy, Cormac
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Post-chaotic post-nuclear holocuast post-armageddon is a fascination genre amongst those who look for insight in dystopic literature. The craze is mosPost-chaotic post-nuclear holocuast post-armageddon is a fascination genre amongst those who look for insight in dystopic literature. The craze is most likely rooted in our attempt to understand the world post-us (I've also heard the theory that Americans are obsessed with our own end in lieu of the horrors of slavery and the native american extermination that began this country in conjunction with a guilty conscience--take that as you will) and see if there is such a thing as reality when humans are no longer real.McCarthy's main difference is that his present happens much after the future amageddon event, which is never revealed, and focuses on how two characters survive after all the non-perishables are consummed.It's a good story and can be read in a couple sittings; the disjointed narrative and unfocused prose also lend to the dire situation the characters find themselves in. As with all stories or art forms that examine humanity at its weakest, a glimmer of light, a fire if you will, shines from our insides to suggest people are good, when you get down to it. Who doesn't like that message?I can't believe Oprah cared about this book....more

title: And the Hippos Were Boiled in Their Tanks

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What a surprise!A friend surprised me with this books, which I did not know even existed. As a biased Kerouac fan, I was already expectant of a novel What a surprise!A friend surprised me with this books, which I did not know even existed. As a biased Kerouac fan, I was already expectant of a novel that would rank classically with other Beat greats such as On the Road and "Howl"; ATHWBITT is an "archived" novel co-written by Kerouac and William S. Burroughs before either were noteworthy for their more famous novels about an incident that almost implicated both in a murder.The most startling thing for me reading this and the other Beat works is that while I maintain a certain distain and dare I say disgust for their lifestyle, I have an insatiable and morbid fascination and dare I say lust for the literature. It's difficult for me to comprehend how they could have lived the way they did, so self destructive, so impulsive; but it's more difficult for me to understand why I'm drawn to it. Perhaps it's cathartic. Perhaps I'm envious, somewhere in the recesses of a truer less conservative, less in bed strictly by 10:30 self.At any rate, it's classic Beat all the way and it was a long time coming. Kerouac's long lost (perhaps first) novel....more

title: The Scarlet Letter
author: Hawthorne, Nathaniel
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's difficult to ignore cultural literary staples in their calling from the past (or perhaps our professor's mouths) earnestly wanting to be read. SoIt's difficult to ignore cultural literary staples in their calling from the past (or perhaps our professor's mouths) earnestly wanting to be read. So, ever so often, I'll pick up one of those books I "should have read" and field a plethora of expected questions such as "how many times have you read that?" followed by exasperated exhales and overzealous over-amplified WHATs when I say, "zero, this is the first."The Scarlet Letter is one of the most famous books you probably didn't read unless a high school or college English teacher made you. It goes without saying that 19th century American literature is not at the pinnable of our popular literature, but there is an intrinsic value to its reading. Wait, maybe those teachers weren't so foolish afterall.So we'll link Hawthorne with Emerson and Thoreau and maybe Whitman, those with transcendentalist throughts of individualism and creative seclusion. What we really get when we just read the words, however, is a bright defamation of puritanism that Hawthorne cannot help himself to restrain.Affected personally by his anscetors' participation in the Salem Witch Trails, Hawthorne seems to aim to make reparations by defaming the strict orthodox laws of coloniol puritan American (Boston). In short, a woman is punished vindictivly and (according to our modern standards, at least) unnecessarily for a "menial" crime and the reader gets to see how foolish it all is, especially considering the heroine protagonist accepts and feels she deserves the punishment (feminists?).Fortunately for her, the Puritans often chose more harsh punishments than embroidery, such as, the removal of ears or death.The book is full of great wordplay and is a bit verbose, as was most writing in the time period, but a quick read and well worth it.The first chapter, by far, is the best....more

review: I bought this book because I was on my way to visit his house in Key West and I wanted to get Hemingway's view of Key West around when he lived there;I bought this book because I was on my way to visit his house in Key West and I wanted to get Hemingway's view of Key West around when he lived there; not to mention that as far as hits and misses goes, his hits have slaughtered the inexistant misses.THAHN is a short novel that tells multiple disorganized perspectives of a strange and quasi-interrelated story. Our main protagonist, Harry Morgan, sometimes speaks from the first person, and other times is spoken of by a narrater. Interlaced into his evolving narrative is a bizarre love story of the rich and debaucherous and communist revolutions in Cuba.Oh, and about 20 pages before the end, he introduces 10 new characters. Hemingway.But, as usual, it's not the story itself but the way he tells it that makes this novel and all of his work so appealing. There are equal parts brutality and compassionate love. I suppose, in a way, Hemingway's done a good job observing how real people live real life....more

title: A Mercy
author: Morrison, Toni
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Beloved is perhaps the most recognizable and Oprah-made-famous book by the nobel prize winning author who focuses primarily on African American historBeloved is perhaps the most recognizable and Oprah-made-famous book by the nobel prize winning author who focuses primarily on African American history, slave narrative, and women's subjugation: Toni Morrison. A Mercy, her latest to date, follows a similar trend. This novel, set in rural slave-ridden Virginia before America's independence, focuses on different perspectives of three slaves, their mistress and their master in what seems to be each's struggle with aloneness dispite proximity. Throughout the book, it seems that this motley group froms almost a sort of family, living cohesively and at times, seemingly, happily; but circumstance (pox) and the inevitable realization that indentured servitude is a fancy word for imprisonment unravels all of the lives that Morrison creates.The best part of the novel is that it is split up into different perspectives, giving the book what seems like different narratives, or short stories. From the first person "uneducated" ranting of a lovestruck running (not illegally) slave girl to omnipresent third-person narration back at the plantation, Morrison tells multiple stories together into one tight bundle that reinforces our need to understand our horrific history and understand our constant human selves.Like most of her books, she succeeds most in her use of colloquial post-contemporary writing and the non-linear plot lines....more

title: The New York Trilogy        (New York Trilogy #1-3)
author: Auster, Paul
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Well, it reads faster than Lord of the Rings, as far as trilogies go.Paul Auster wrote three detective novels that break the traditional standard of wWell, it reads faster than Lord of the Rings, as far as trilogies go.Paul Auster wrote three detective novels that break the traditional standard of what it means to detect, investigate, and deduce; and bundled them up in a "trilogy" that reflects the self as much as it does the urban landscape. In an age where the best-selling authors are thriller-suspense mystery pop once-a-month bogies (see Evanovich, Clancy, King, Patterson, etc), Auster almost pokes fun at the genre by flipping the proverbial tables on the art of the sleuth. In essence, his detectives are always investigating a case, but in truth, are investigating themselves. Perhaps the most striking characteristic of the three books is the way Auster plays with names. In the first book alone, the title character Quinn writes under the pseudonym Wilson who has a character named Work and is confused with Auster (a name used in the books which obviously references the author's own self investigation through his characters). In the second book, Ghosts, the characters' names are colors. This fact brings interesting concepts to the proverbial table, which he's already flipped.There is little that makes these books a trilogy, in the sense that they do not relate to one another (besides vague throw-ins for the faithful Auster reader), but thematically, the books remind us again and again that looking out is just another facet of looking in....more

title: The Last Man
author: Shelley, Mary
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Though I have a penchant for non-canonical books of canonical authors, Shelley's The Last Man is much more laborious than say Frankenstein. It's nearyThough I have a penchant for non-canonical books of canonical authors, Shelley's The Last Man is much more laborious than say Frankenstein. It's nearyly 500 pages long and my edition is roughly 8 point font, so I found myself walking around in a blurred stupor the remainder of any day I read. Still, the book is written almost entirely in poetic verse, so while the reader wonders when the 18% of the novel that actually makes up the plot (and rest assured, I'm not a plot driven writer/reader) will appear, he/she gets a vivid and constantly beautiful image of the story. Shelley really has a knack for inflating things to realize their full beauty and potential. As for as the the story is concerned, TLM is about a plague that destroys humanity, leaving the sole member to comprehend life without companions or society. The only problem is, said plague is first mentioned around pg. 170 and without ruining too much for potential readers, there isn't a lot of introspective lonely discourse when humans are finally wiped out. Still, if you're willing to risk the eyesight, and you want to read what ends up being a great book of poetry with some good story concepts interlaced, I'd say check it out.The novel did make me look at people in the subway or standing in line at Dunkin Doughnuts a little differently. That's something, isn't it?...more

title: For Whom the Bell Tolls
author: Hemingway, Ernest
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm afraid that after reading this, I will be forever disappointed in all other novels. Rarely do I give such distinguished praise for a book, but HemI'm afraid that after reading this, I will be forever disappointed in all other novels. Rarely do I give such distinguished praise for a book, but Hemingway's is quite deserving. Hemingway writes in a way that makes other writers envious in that his story is so simple and strong yet human, complex, and fragile. Centered around a very small mission in a war most Americans (myself included) know/knew nothing about, FWTBT is really about the intracacy of relationships as they morph over stressful situation and regular life happenstance. What really sets Hemingway apart is that his writing is provokatively honest and insightful. At times, his reader has that persistent pit in their stomach in regard to the graphic nature of the material, and at other times, feels the red-wine-warmth of a truism that only he can articulate. It's the honesty of everything we want to admit about ourselves if we were to ever give ourselves the chance.I big book, but one of the ones you'll regret to finish.It tolls for thee....more

title: Satori in Paris & Pic
author: Kerouac, Jack
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: As a writer, Kerouac has commented that he does whatever he can to ensure he doesn't talk badly about anyone. It's hard then, to talk badly about him.As a writer, Kerouac has commented that he does whatever he can to ensure he doesn't talk badly about anyone. It's hard then, to talk badly about him. Or perhaps, it's difficult because of the writing itself. As perhaps the most influencial writer of the infamous "beat" generation but moreover all Americans not satiated with the downtrodden lifestyle of conformed monotony, Kerouac now brings his readers to Paris for the last volume of his Douloz (sp) Legend. Although it is no "Big Sur," Kerouac again uses his sharp wit and tactfull distaste for grammatic boundaries to craft a novel about. . .wait for it. . .you might guess. . .here it comes. . .travel. But it never gets old. I want to read about everywhere this man went. Like Walt Whitman, Kerouac is able to celebrate the things most people mourn. He didn't live the most happy life, and he certainly abused alcohol. But he paid for it, and the humanity that ensues is nothing less than captured in his books. I would say that "Big Sur" is a better conclusion to his lifelong saga than "Satori," but seriously, who am I?As for "Pic," it sort of reminds me of a Mark Twain with Pictorial Review (Pic) really playing a modern day Huckleberry Finn (Huck). What do you think?...more

author: Zelitch, Simone*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Louisa is a "lost book" that can be found and bought on Amazon.com for a penny, but in no way should be lost upon readers. It's a beautifully written Louisa is a "lost book" that can be found and bought on Amazon.com for a penny, but in no way should be lost upon readers. It's a beautifully written story that turns the tables on the concept of the holocaust by juxtaposing a German girl in post-WWII Isreal. The girl's trials with wanting to convert to Judaism and being discriminated against for her national origin articulate an obvious and overlooked fact: that hatred is similar despite who is hating, and it is never justified, and always blind.Be this as it may, it is not the story's main focus. Our narrator, Nora, is a Hungarian Jew who joins the countless Diaspora after the war. Her journey and struggle reflect a sort of hopeless resignation forced upon the psyches of those whom this travesty was inflicted.The book is written in coherent and well-crafted passages, and Zelitch brings us catchy one-liners throughout that emphasize the tragedy of being human, and in relation, the beauty....more

title: The Mysterious Stranger
author: Twain, Mark
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It is no surprise that Mark Twain shows up with a glaring five stars next to his book's title. The fact remains, Twain was perhaps one of America's prIt is no surprise that Mark Twain shows up with a glaring five stars next to his book's title. The fact remains, Twain was perhaps one of America's premiere writers.In The Mysterious Stranger, traditional readers of Twain will get a nuanced view of the Mississippian-river-style writer. Where we may be more familier with Twain's depiction and dialect of the south and the adventuous nature of young boys, TMS is a metaphysical exploration of the purpose of humanity.It was almost a shock to witness Twain's extensive and eclectic vocabulary, being that his normal colloquial vocabulary of the south is so "dumbed" down. Here, in TMS, he is uniquely eloquent and picturesque. The story itself, really just a 100-page mini novella, attempts to comprehend the nature of mankind, something it seems Twain may have been struggling with. He goes to some length describing how outright horrible mankind has been in its historic decisions.Toward the end, I was getting a little leery as to whether or not this was Twain's final point because I did not consider him to be so cynical. And from a humanist perspective, absolute cynicism about the nature of mankind is shortsighted, and undeveloped. Thankfully, Twain pulls back from this, and at the very end, gives a highly philosophical and (dare I say) Eastern (Hindu) concept of the "purpose" of mankind. And although Twain presents this a little melancholically, I took great relief in his assessments.Good and worthwhile read....more

Her novels are usually so full of wonderful imagery, dry wit, and sociological commentary, that I was almost dumbfounded that this monotonus book was dripped from the same pen as The Handmaid's Tale and Alias Grace.TRB is a dry and slow moving accound of three women none of us would really like to hang out with as they struggle internally with a fourth woman none of us would really like to hang out with. Oh, and in the mix, are a few men who accidentily hang out with all said women and end up worse for the wear. I'm not sure what Atwood's main concept was for this novel, but she fell short of it.I wrote my master's thesis on gender studies and used Atwood as my main source of argument. title: The Love of the Last Tycoon
author: Fitzgerald, F. Scott
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm not precisely sure why this book effected me the way it did, but it certainly did. Fitzgerald finished writing the fifth chapter of this book befoI'm not precisely sure why this book effected me the way it did, but it certainly did. Fitzgerald finished writing the fifth chapter of this book before he had a heart attack and died. When you get to the end of this unfinished novel, you find the last word one of the greatest American writers ever wrote. Something about this is chilling. And despite the fact that one can not make any substantial investment in characters who we know in advance we'll never know completely or whose stories we won't ever realize; there is something in the simplistic and honest quality of this novel that pits it amongst Fitzgerald's greats. He himself said in his notes and letters to friends that he had no fear in writing this novel and that it was to most resemble Gatsby, but in a new way. He wanted to expose things to people in nuanced ways. My version came with the author's original outline and plot synopsis so you can piece together the original intention; but what is really important is what you get: a concise look at the small chances of love in big people. Calamity in the real world. What you get is Fitzgerald's last hurrah; his final statement. What you get, is a novel that could have been, and is enough....more

title: Choke
author: Palahniuk, Chuck*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Although Palahnuik has recently decided to err on the side of the grotesque as opposed to producing quality literature (humble disappointed Palahniuk Although Palahnuik has recently decided to err on the side of the grotesque as opposed to producing quality literature (humble disappointed Palahniuk fan), Choke is one of his earlier books that falls short of his unique and challenging writing style. After my second read (in preparation for the forthcoming feature film), I still feel as if Choke lacks what makes his other novels so good, namely, a story and characters you can't help but caring about. You end up caring about them like you do a suspicious mole, but it's still care, after all. Where Chuck succeeds in this novel is in his traditional post-modern disjointed narrative approach. He writes in a style that would make most classic literature afficianados (sp?) cringe. And his one liners are almost always philsophically poignant. What you'll miss here, is any real kind of plot or social commentary, the way you get masculinity in modern culture like in Fight Club or sexuality and vanity the way you do in Invisible Monsters. All things considered though, it's clever, short, and an easy read. See also: a must for any Palahniuk fan.See also: tips on how to have sex in an airplane....more

review: Frankle's psychological theory--logotherapy--suggests that suffering is necessary in developing the human psyche and that purpose despite suffereing iFrankle's psychological theory--logotherapy--suggests that suffering is necessary in developing the human psyche and that purpose despite suffereing is perhaps man's greatest "meaning." Although this theory is in no way novel (see many Eastern religions), it is presented here through the lens of the Holocaust, which of course gives it a unique clout. The whole first chapter is devoted to Frankle's time spent in various concentration camps, which despite the redundancy and anachronistic stream-of-schizophrenic-consciousness writing, would be an interesting read for those, well, interested in WWII. The rest of this short book, over and over, states that establishing a meaning is man's greatest chore and most splendid endeavor. (In essence, now, you can just read the first chapter). The only other truly enigmatic aspect of the book is when Frankle says the prisoners were more likely to feel sad during Christmas time, because they could not spend the holiday with their family. To which I retorted to the book, "I didn't think Jews celebrated Christmas." ...more
